content:
ber 7, 2016
Short preview: (+) Enough good story. ✅  (+) Long game-time length. ✅ It was 61 hours for me, with side-quests, “assignments”,.  (+) Customizable dialogue. ✅ Click here to see it!   (-) It doesn’t run on Windows 7 – 64 bit, even with changed compatible mods. ✗ It’s fixable with an official patch, click here![masseffect.bioware.com] (-) Sometimes the body and face animations lags at the end of sentence. ✗  (-) There’s not enough action, shooting. ✗  Crashes / Bugs / Glitches:After I had updated it to v.1.2, and was able to run, I had a weird glitch, which was that the keyboard rarely refused to work in the game. I had to use ALT+TAB+Delete and restart the game. Without keyboard, I couldn’t save it before the had the process stopped. :(  My personal opinion:Unfortunately, this game has many minor flaws. Rarely / sometimes the voice acting didn’t match to the correct character behaviour. For example; I was in a calm conversation and the other character was in trouble, and I would have liked to offer my help ‘Can I help you?’, but Shepard said, ’What do you want?’, in a rather rude way. :(  The 40% of the game-play was a talking simulator (with all side quests) for me. I found myself in a good action at the beginning, and when we docked in the Citadel, I had talked and walked place to place for 9 hours, in that same giant spaceship the Citadel! Fortunately, they were not too long, but a lot of! When I began to bore it, fortunately, I managed to start the second main mission and left the Citadel.  The side quests rather repetitive, go to planet to planet, kill them, bring that, talk with them.  BUT! ALL AFTER THESE! The story blew up and gave me a desperate interesting! The last 30% of the game was absolutely cool and interesting for me! And I knew then, that the sort of boring 70% of game-play was needed. To get to know the other civilisations, species, their life and habits. They all needed for the complete feeling! At the end of the game, I was rally happy that I’ve bough this game and finished it. ✅  Recommendation:Despite the many minor flaws, I was happy to get to know this story/game. I can recommend it to them who;  Like Sci-fi stories.  Like to talk with non human species.  Like to behave as you are. (Or at least similar what you are.)  Like to discover other planets. (Sort of open world)  Future atmosphere.  Like or bear to do repetitive side-quests.  Achievement hunting:There’s no Steam achievements, but there’s in-game achievements. So, your Average-Steam-Achievement-Rate won’t increase or decrease with this game. It was a good news for me. ✅

number of helpful: 19 of 21 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2014
												Mass Effect games are always fun to talk about, never sure if I love or hate them more.The 1st game in the series undoubtedly plays most like an RPG of the 3 games, though even then, it would stand as a rather odd RPG when compared to others. For those that have played BioWare's best work: Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic, you'll notice some similar sub-stories, characters, and styles. I mention this only because the influence is strongest in the 1st game, when the series hasn't really defined itself completely.Anyways, it stands as the black sheep of the trilogy for its odd mix of RPG and 3rd person shooter mechanics. It does, however, possess strengths the others lack. The Lovecraftian horror influence is pretty clear in some of the side quests that take you to remote planets -- the fear of the unknown, the ominous music all play into this. The vehicular sections on the remote planets are a bit clunky, but they do a good job of establishing mystery -- you don't know quite what you're going to find. This works well in both reinforcing the trilogy's whole narrative and the general style the narrative embodies: the unknown, powerful threat, the dirty/dark sci-fi.Of course, one has to forgive the incessantly repeated interiors and textures for the side quests, this game lacks polish. If one can get past it, one will find a series of stories that help add to and fill in Mass Effect's universe, even setting things up for the sequels well.If one does everything, the game will take roughly 45-50 hours. If one moves through the narrative alone, you can complete it in 10-15 hours. The main story narrative has the strongest KOTOR infuence. KOTOR was a campaign across a series of planets, not an entire galaxy. Mass Effect too, is composed of fairly long missions on a small handful of planets -- each a sort of individual story that connects to the larger narrative. Or there's the fact that in both KOTOR and ME1, the player follows the antagonist, or rather retraces their steps, to discover their motivations and goals, across different planets. This is contrasted, then, with Mass Effect 2 and 3, where the meat of the games is composed of much more compact and exposition heavy missions with a lot of tight, polished shooting across many locations.The shooting mechanics seem to, in principle, be based on what many call a Gears of War or GTAIV cover based system. Player pops in and out of cover. However, it's pretty clunky, the player doesn't stick too well to cover and cannot navigate it very well. Add in the fact that weapons, armor, and upgrades are doled out in a traditional RPG manner, with damage stats being compared, unique drops, the skill point based system of character leveling. and a huge inventory to sort through, and one will begin to notice that things seem out of place.  It is not so much that these elements are bad in and of themselves, but more that they don't belong together. As if the developers were unsure of what kind of game they wanted Mass Effect to be.After several replays, I've come to realize that they don't do a very good job of leading up to what is supposed to be the central twist of the narrative, the big reveal about the focus of the whole trilogy, the thing to make the games all connect. Avoiding spoilers, I mean the event with the 'virtual intelligence' on Virmire late in the game. Anyone replaying will notice that the game will go so far as to basically tell, through other characters, the player directly what the narrative reveals later in a manner obviously meant to be climactic. It is again, odd, unpolished, and atypical of BioWare, much like the entirety of the game.**SPOILERS AHEAD**Besides feeling out of place and sometimes unpolished, the game has a lot of content, has mechanics that work even if feeling awkward, and manages to present an engaging narrative -- I still get rather excited when Joker commands the fleet upon Sovereign in one of the final scenes. Mass Effect's cinematic presentation is fantastic and never fails to make me feel invested in the story. (If, again, one can forgive some of the cliches like checking the body of the villain to make sure he's dead only to discover him alive or thinking the hero is dead only to have him reemerge triumphantly. I think it is possible to view these little storytelling sins sympathetically, cute little mistakes of young Mass Effect)I spent around 150 hours (100 on my Steam copy) on this game over several playthroughs. As I said at the beginning, I have a lot of issues with the series and it definitely isn't perfect. I can't deny though, that they do some things so well, and are so unique that they are games we can conclude are worth playing, worth discussing, worth evaluating.Despite the game's flaws, odd qualities, and weird inability to define itself, I have to recommend it for all it does well, for starting a great trilogy and for leading into the best game of the series: Mass Effect 2.

												Mass Effect, or as I like to call it, Extreme Drag Racing, is a game that you must play at some point in your video game career. Not because it's famous, or because it defines the sci-fi RPG genre. No; you must play this game because it has heart. It's captivating beyond anything you can fathom. I applaud all the developers who created this game, because they knew what they were doing. Does the game have flaws? Of course! What game doesn't? Have you played Fallout 4? So any excuse of, "Oh, this game is too old" or "Oh, this game has bad graphics" or even "Oh, there are already 3 sequels to this game (almost)" is...well inexcusable. So please, if you consider yourself a gamer of any level, or any genre, this game is one that you must add to your library of experiences. Trust me, it'll be worth it. Shepard out.

content:
20, 2014
												Mass Effect is a Sci-Fi Third-Person Shooter/RPG. The game is set a few hundred years into the future, where humanity has discovered FTL travel and other intelligent life. You play as Commander Shepard. AI called the Geth have been attacking human colonies across the galaxy, and it's up to you to stop them. Along the way you will travel to numerous planets, meeting and helping many different species. As you go along, you unravel the mystery of why the Geth have been attacking humans. The story is absolutely amazing. One of the last few good games developed by BioWare. You make a ton of choices throughout the game, which impact both the ending, and the sequels to the game. The combat is great too. A challenging tactical third-person shooter. Each battle requires you to plan ahead, otherwise you will be overpowered very quickly. If you are playing on harder difficulties, one wrong move could mean the end of the battle. This makes for some really tense situations. There is an inventory system which allows you to customise you and your squad's armour and weapons. Plus add modifications to them. The interface for this can be annoying, especially when you have a ton of gear. But it's not too bad, and having the ability to upgrade weapons and armour is a great addition to the game. Overall, Mass Effect is an amazing Western RPG/TPS. One of my favourite games of all time. I would recommend this to anyone.

content:
, 2016
												My first 'real' RPG and my introduction to the trilogy as a whole. Mass Effect 1 is an excellent game that's aged pretty well, though there are still some hiccups here and there.Pros:-An immersive story where most choices have long-standing consequences. These range from fairly obvious galactic-scale choices to something as seemingly inconsequential as chatting with a particular NPC. While not all of these are terribly important, it really gives a sense of connectivity between games. People don't just forget how you treated them in the past.-The planetary exploration system. While it's unfortunately coupled with the horrible Mako controls (talked about in more detail below), this is one often-derided part of the game that I actually enjoyed. By having a planet in nearly every system that you can get down and explore (rather than just scanning from your ship, as in later games) makes the galaxy seem that much more massive.-The universe itself. Like most Bioware RPGs, the universe of the game is incredibly fleshed out. You'll discover hundreds of 'codex entries', which are little articles which describe how things work in-universe. Everything from spaceship design, to FTL travel, to how certain aliens function is covered at some point or another. This is all optional, of course- you don't *have* to know any of it to play the game, but it really enhances the experience when you can see how much thought went into creating this world.Cons:-The inventory system is... not great. I've seen worse, even in AAA titles, but this one is pretty bad. Your inventory will quickly become cluttered with mostly useless junk, with only a few things worth keeping. This does a good job of fleshing out the world somewhat (most things have a small description or at least a logo, making the galaxy feel bigger), but at the cost of convenience. You practically have to micromanage your squadmate's armor and guns for the first half of the game or so. Once you get access to the really good stuff, everything else becomes pretty much obsolete. Credits become kind of superfulous at the end of the game as well- I maxed out my bank on my first run without even really trying.-The dreaded Mako. It's essentially an armored vehicle for planetary exploration. Sounds great, right? The problem is that the handling is utterly atrocious. The thing lumbers around like a drunken rhinocerous, until it gets stuck on a rock outcropping and flies halfway across the map. It's all right to drive on a flat surface, but most planets are at least somewhat mountainous. There are even a few that are almost nothing but hills. Once again, this adds character to the planets at the expense of gameplay. Everything else:-The combat's nothing special. Not bad, mind you, but it doesn't do a whole lot that's really unique. Third-person shooting from behind chest-high walls with some different powers to liven things up. These range from hacking robotic enemies or weapons to 'biotic' powers which are essentially Force moves. The AI for enemies can get a bit stupid at times with characters running straight into your ambushes. -The graphics are good. A lot of the planetary environments are still beautiful, but some of the characters can get off-model mid-cutscene which makes things pretty jarring. Overall, I'd rate this a solid 9/10. Good combat, if nothing new, coupled with a wonderfully rich environment, engaging characters, and long-lasting consequences that will follow you through the trilogy.

												Mass Effect is my favorite series I have ever played. You can really understand and learn about the characters in the game as you play it. It is an older game now sure, but even in 2016 it doesn't look bad at all. There are also mods to help revamp the graphics and lighting that are easy to get set up right for you. This game has pretty okay replayablity as well. Different classes with very different abilites, different choices to make throught the game. Play through at least two times to get Paragon (good cop) and Renegade (bad cop) options, and you can hit most of the dialouges this way as well. It has amazing soundtracks, voice acting, unique character races, lots of lore and story, all around a really great experiance. You can play this game and not the second or third, and still be able to have fun with the story. Though when I played this game years ago, I just had to play the second and third. To this day, to be able to sit down, play Mass Effect, import my character and thier decisions to Mass Effect 2, and import again to Mass Effect 3, and have nearly 150-200 hours put into this one character, is special. It isn't a new character the next game, it is my character. It is everything I want them to be, and the same goes to all the other characters that went with me along the way. It is making your own story with you and your team. Making relationships, friendships, working through hardships, all done together. I absolutely recommend this game, and the entire series. Roleplay, storytelling, engaging characters and enviornment, everything makes it special. 10/10 experiance with my time with it all

content:
er 19, 2013
												Mass Effect is brilliant. It has that incredible "feel" that I constantly look for in games.The combat is often turned down by many players as they find it difficult to deal with and boring, but I think that it's a nice addition to this game's originality! It's a lot different than combat in most games, but that doesn't make it bad -  at all -  for me.The music. Oh man, the music. Whenever I hear for example "Vigil", "Vampire Ride", "Liara's World", past the halfway of "Uplink" or any Citadel song, I feel great. The amazing music is a major part of ME's memorable atmosphere, though not the only one.The galaxy is huge! There are several systems and beneath those star clusters to explore. On the planets' surface, you drive the 100% badass Mako. The vehicle has got positive and negative feeback - I don't quite understand how anyone could diss that beast!Lots of characters from several different interesting species. I love every single one! In fact, at first I was totally annoyed and frustrated by the small ball-y Volus, but now I always grin at them! They're so silly!I grew to really care about and like the squad mates. The alien ones, at least - they're the most interesting! There is a tough guy from the Krogan species - they always remind me of toads for some reason.  In the summer, there are some toads and frogs in my pond out in the yard - I should name one of them Wrex! Gotta love him!Definitely one of the very best games I've ever played. The spacey sci-fi world is marvelous. The only space game that I would consider even better is Star Control II, a classic from -92. But ME is a certain number two!And there are two MORE of these games! How much better can this enjoyment get?

er 17, 2010
												Mass Effect is quite possibly the most amazing game ever written for a video game, recalling many of the best elements from some of the greatest works of the sci-fi genre and putting you in an almost "Oblivion"-like level of control over the world. You could spend dozens of hours simply exploring unknown worlds and building your fortune that way while shirking the main story altogether if you choose. But if you don't have all the time in the universe to enjoy this one, the main story is not too long. In fact, I honestly wish it were much longer, but that was the sacrifice made for the open-ended freedom of exploration the player is given. One will most likely spend upwards of 50 hours just exploring the galaxies and discovering all of the tiny stories within the story that really flesh this universe out. Plus, there are many different ways to play the game which will command you to replay it over again just to see all of the what-if's and enjoy mastering all of the various class sort.

content:
ry 27
												The first Mass Effect is one of the games that make me want a third, neutral recommendation option here on Steam. On one hand, I love this game, I've finished it 3-4 times - recently here on Steam (in preparation for Andromeda) and a few times using the boxed version and while I enjoy the game a lot now, I remember my first time playing it and I also remember dropping the game after an hour or two, simply because it didn't appeal to me at the time. I came back after I finished playing ME 2 (which I loved the moment I started playing), because I wanted to fill in some leftover plot holes, made by skipping the first game. I'm glad I did it that way, if I forced myself to play ME1 first, I might've really hated the game and it would make me skip out the whole series as I would assume the games are all "bad" or they don't appeal to me, because let's face it - ME 1 has many flaws.Let's list some cons:The first thing you'll notice - only low resolution options and no borderless support (and I didn't find a way to enable it even with usage of external programs), also the graphics are rather mediocre for 2007 (use 1st Bioshock for comparison).Most interiors are copy&pasted, recycled content - get ready to go through the same exact building 20 timesExteriors are not exactly original either, seems like they used some sort of random gen script for most planets, then altered the textures, placed that one building I mentioned above, put one of 3 types of enemies inside, scattered like 2-3 other "events" across the map (usually mining or a container with items) and now and then they added a "quest" which involves Admiral Heckett contacting you after you fly to a new location, saying something generic like "hurr durr there's a bunch of scientists needing your help, we rely on you, Shepard"Combat is very clunky - I hope they fired whoever came up with the idea of snipers that instakill you and hit you every time. Krogans and some Geth that run at you no matter what are not very fun either.Combat on higher difficulties is difficult not because the enemies would get smarter, it's because of the mechanics above. You still get one-shot, just more often.Enemy variety - 80% of the time you fight the Geth, 10% Humans, the rest is split among the other races (mostly Rachni, Batarians, Krogans...)Class and quest/kill reward balancing is awfulApparently the same balancing team did class balancing, as some classes are obviously a lot stronger than others.Bugs (and I don't mean the big bugs - Rachni, I mean actual bugs), getting stuck is not that uncommon. Sometimes you're not even sure what's a bug and what's a feature. For example - there's a quest on citadel that makes you go find 21 NPCs that are scattered around the city. Not only the place is huge, it's also really confusing as the map is pretty much useless. 'Till this day I still don't know where the 21st NPC is (or if the quest bugged for me). I'll never know what the quest reward is (probably something worthless, like 500 credits)The voice acting is 50/50 either great or terrible. The female Shepard voice actress is awesome, while the male actor sounds very stiff and boring.Why even play the game with all those flaws you ask?Well, the story is amazing. Not the exploration side quests - let's not talk about those. But the actual main story is great, all the backstory on every race and every individual makes you really interested in what happened and what happens next. While I think that Bioware is a rather "lazy" studio when it comes to game development (I'm looking at you, Dragon Age 2), I'd say that their storywriters are among the best in the industry. Also most importantly - this game is the prequel to the actual Mass Effect game - Mass Effect 2. Mostly everything that was wrong with ME1 is fixed in ME2 and while they are both very good games, ME2 is way more "new-gen-player" friendly, easier, more modern and fun to play. So that is my recommendation - play through ME2 first and if you enjoy the game, you'll be eager to play ME1 as well and if you don't enjoy its gameplay, you'll at least enjoy the story, that's for sure. I think the flaws of ME1 that some of us overlooked back in 2007 didn't age well, nowadays we seek more refined games - like ME2. However, the story is just as good as it used to be, so it's definitely worth a playthrough.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2015
												This game really did it for me. While not flawless the gameplay experience it gave me was among the best I have yet to encounter in my gaming 'career'. Apart from my first playthrough of Final Fantasy 7 and, of course, Mass Effect 2 nothing comes to my mind that holds up in comparison.The premise does not seem that extraordinary at first glance. You play as Commander Shepard (either male or female, your choice) and basically you are going to prevent the annihilation of every major civilisation in the galaxy. Pretty standard so far. But the world building in this game is so complex, so detailled it blew me away.Every now and then you get entries in your Codex where you can read about the many spacefaring races, some important historic events or the different technologies you are utilizing in the game. I loved how they put that much effort into something many gamers won't even bother to read because it is not important at all if you just want to progress the story.What really makes the game come to life is its host of memorable characters. There are innumerable people you encounter, many of which can be spoken with, often offering multiple dialogue-tree options. Some of those will join your team and become your companions. Since I engaged all of my companions in conversations regularly between missions I started to really care about them. They are fully fleshed out personalities, each with his own motivations and wishes.The main villains, the Reapers, are mostly only hinted at. But you never forget them and their looming presence in the background gives the story a dire urgency. The Reapers' henchmen you are battling are nothing grand but they serve their purpose well.The gameplay combines elements of roleplaying, shooter and exploration games and the result gave me great joy. There were some rather unpleasant moments while traversing the surface of the more mountainous planets but thankfully there weren't that many of them. The majority of the game is spent either engaging NPCs in conversations or shooting at  enemies. Both aspects are done very well, although the shooter portion got a tiny bit repetitive at the end. But since I did every available sidequest and played almost nonstop for several days until I was done that might be my own fault.The skillsystem is solid and you get tons of loot to equip your characters with.There are several occasions when you have to make a decision that will have repercussions in the later games. Some are more personal and affect if a specific character will survive to come back in the sequels. Some have a galactic impact. In one case you decide between exterminating an entire race or giving them another chance. All of these moments came back to me vividly while playing Mass Effect 2 and being confronted with the consequences of my own actions.

content:
er 25, 2015
												First of all, this game is nearly 8 years old (as of now). In newer machines it’ll require some tweaking to acquire the best results. Some things are unavoidable though, for instance, the max resolution is 720p, but other issues can be improved. In my experience the “motion blur” setting didn’t work out well: Shepard was always “shaking”. Other issue was the V-sync setting: no matter what I did, it simply wouldn’t work, the game was always at 62~63 fps and I would see screen-tearing literally all the time. Luckily there’s an easy solution for this: I simply activated triple-buffering in the GPU settings, overriding the game settings (then I activated V-sync in the game settings and restarted it: problem solved). Another issue was the Steam Overlay: in order for it to work with the game, I needed to open Steam as an administrator (Win 8.1).Now that the technical issues are taken care of, let’s see the pros and cons:Pros:•	Massive game: at least 30 hours of gameplay are guaranteed.•	Over the top replayability value: you can play as Renegade, Paragon or any mixture of both. Your choices will affect not only the story of ME 1, but also the subsequent titles of the franchise.•	The game is funny. Although Shepard appears to be serious, there’s a subtle humor to many of his lines/actions.•	Outstanding voice-work: Seth Green (Joker), Keith David (Captain Anderson), and Mark Meer (Shepard) are incredible. Overall, the whole cast is consistent.•	You can punch a NPC for no apparent reason.•	Engaging story and interesting characters/classes/settings: Reapers, Protheans, Quarians, Krogans, Keepers, Turians, Volus, The Citadel, The Council, Mass Relays, etc… there’s a whole new sci-fi mythology to be found.•	Great graphics for 2008: even though the graphics might seem outdated nowadays, they were really impressive back in 2008.•	You’ll get to drive the best off-road vehicle ever: the Mako.Cons:•	You can’t romance everyone.•	You’ll get lost in Ilos, no matter what you do.•	In the beginning you’ll have a hard time finding your significant ones inside the Normandy.•	You’ll be annoyed by Shepard’s lack of endurance training (he can’t sprint for 200 meters without getting exhausted).

												What if I told you there was a science-fiction roleplaying game where you lead a vastly diverse crew to stop the Council's golden agent after he goes rogue?Now, what if I told you that in said game, you make choices that can drastically effect multiple boss fights and just how diverse your crew is?Now stay with me, what if I told you in said game, your dialogue tree has VOICED dialogue provided by Mark Meer (if you are playing male) or the lovely Jennifer Hale (if you are playing female, obviously.)Okay, okay, sound interesting? Now how about this... What if I told you that this is Part 1 to a fully thought out and innovative trilogy where you can import not only your saves, but your very character (from your choices to your appearance) from the first game?What if I told you this game also has low enough specs to be played on most laptops? Seriously, if you're a RPG fan and you haven't played this yet because the controversy of the third game's ending has discouraged you: play this trilogy anyways. This is a lore-filled game with a fully narrated codex. A fully narrated codex!!! You can spend hours just listening to the codex alone!Seriously, the entire trilogy will provide you hundreds of hours of immersion in a well crafted universe.Just buy this if you like roleplaying games of any sort.

y 11, 2015
												Mass Effect is a good game, but not as good as you would expect from review rating. In the start, it's even boring. I nearly wanted to quit it – with all those lengthy dialogues, walking around doing nothing, shooting nobody...With lousy controls, inconvenient maps, generic exploration missions and awful combat system, you almost want to hate it, but THEN, in the second third of the game, the story gets better, creating emotional attachment to the characters, revealing sinister plot of epic proportion and pushing you to make game-changing moral choices, you're getting more and more excited and want to find out what's going to happen next. After the final battle you're like "WOW! That was something!" But is a great story enough to define this game as great? I don't think so. Every other aspect in this game is bad or mediocre.  So I give ME solid 7.5/10.PROS:- Great story (but only after the Citadel intro), although it's too anthropocentric and Commander Sheppard is unrealistically important and popular for a single soldier- Flexible and vast character appearance customisation options- Mods that make the game substantially better (e.g., MEUITM mod)NEUTRAL:- Alternative scenarios, choices matterCONS:- Homogenous textures with poor attention to detail (it might not be possible at the time, but still it doesn't add up to a good experience)- There are times in main missions when autosave feature is not working the entire mission; if you forget to save (which might be a disabled feature, too), you risk starting all over again, which means 10-15 minutes of repeated gameplay- Awful Mako (vehicle) controls, often it goes the opposite direction from what you're stearing it to. Combine it with disabled autosave and falling off the cliff and there you go – repeat the whole mission again- Awful combat system: there are covers, which both you and the AI should be using, but, since everyone (including your squad members) are just chaotically running all over the place, it's just easier to rush forward and shoot everybody without thinking about any tactics- Initial weapons are awfully inaccurate- Inconvenient inventory system (typical RPG thing)- Unbalanced credits system: short of money in the beginning, millionnaire towards the end (another typical RPG thing); but, IMO, it's not worth to purchase anything anyway, you get all you need from looting- Generic exploration missions on another planets with mountainous terrain – it's up and down over the mountains all the time- Mini-map kind of sucks, because it functions only as a radar and it doesn't depict distance properly- Right turn doesn't work sometimes, you have to turn the camera left to enable right turn again- There are no markers for side missions on galaxy map; you have to read the mission description to know where you should go and it's not very convenient- You need to create an EA account to get the free DLCAnyway, with so many faults, I still think this game is worth your time and money, because with such flexible and vast story it was something unique at the time, earning ME a place in the history of video games.P.S. There is a way to enable gamepad support. Check out the guide section!

												Mass Effect is one of the best single player games in any genre that you can play for the best part of a decade. It helped to redefine the genre, and is a must play for fans of rpgs, sci-fi and shooters alike. The graphics are slightly outdated but can be improved with mods. number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
4, 2016
												Ah, Mass Effect. The franchise that has entranced me the most out of everything I've ever played in my life.I remember picking this series up around the time ME2 was already out and people were raving about "Lair of the Shadow Broker". Its final DLC "Arrival" had been announced and was days away from release. The first 2 games were both on sale and I can honestly say they were the best $40 I've ever spent.Right off the bat, what captured me about Mass Effect is the soundtrack. Haunting and alien with a strong 80s Sci-fi vibe. combined with the incredibly immersive visuals of the battle-ravaged landscape of Eden Prime, the first planet we visit during the story.The visuals themselves have a slightly rough edge to them, could be described as "slick retro", but in my view this is what increases ME1's charm and for some reason heightens immersion. Jack Wall & Sam Hulick are a magical team who have pulled out all the stops to truly bring the gameworld to life with the gift of their music.The lore is rich, fascinating and immersive beyond compare. There is enough material to fully supply 100 Mass Effect sequels, because the universe is vast and knows no boundaries. No matter how far-fetching some ideas or concepts might appear, there is no such thing as "unbelievable" when it comes to something so unknowable and alien like Space. Noone knows what's out there.The Mass Effect series is set 170 years into the future, where within the past 30 years humanity has discovered we are not alone in the universe after all. We are but one of numerous sapient species in the Milky Way, and they all have strong opinions too. Yet the galaxy is filled with secrets and one particularly horrifying secret is due to be irreversibly uncovered and put every race in peril. For there are monsters hidden in the dark corners of the Milky Way, and those monsters intend to wipe out all organic life as we know it.Gameplay-wise, ME1 isn't as fluid as other modern shooters. It certainly has its clunky issues and is a little cumbersome at times. Most optional side-quests conclude in identical-looking indoor structures regardless of what planet they're on, making them awfully tedious. The handling of the planetary exploration vehicle, the MAKO, leaves something to be desired, having been described by an in-game character as boasting "handling like a tipsy rhino". I'd say that's being generous.The weapon overheating feature, while designed to add a sense of shooter realism, is more irritating than immersive and will infuriate some people. The inventory system is a primitive, overly cluttered mess and will most certainly irritate some players to no end, but once you get the hang of it you can mostly ignore it.But the punchline is: as clumsy as some game systems are, you can't help but overlook them because the back story will have hooked its claws into you too deep, that you will not be able to stop playing. On a grander scale, overall level design is absolutely breath-taking. Landing on a red moon and looking up to see its main planet covering most of the sky like an angry giant will indeed take your breath away.You're suddenly no longer in your own house, but on an alien world light years away. Driving along the Prothean Skyway on Feros and stopping to soak in the visuals will transport you to 2183 AD. Seeing the Prothean spires stretching beyond atmospheric visibility will project images in your mind, not of a haunted, abandoned world but of a majestic technologically superior empire spanning across the galaxy in all its glory.I ended up completing Mass Effect 1 within 3 days (I took my time) and when I was done, I imported my savegame into Mass Effect 2 and was blown to the stratosphere. Oh yes, hang onto your saves, because you will need them to continue your story in Mass Effect 2. Actions have consequences, and they will shape world details around you.I can go on like this all night, but my point will remain the same. Mass Effect is worth every cent and every second you put in it. I was not a sci-fi fan before Mass Effect; I am now. Even if you're not a fan of elaborate fiction, you can't help but let your mind roam wild when your eyes feast on the stunning futuristic visuals of the Citadel - the cultural galactic center, or the haunting lost alien world of Ilos."Andromeda", the 4th installment of the Mass Effect series is less than a year away from release, and I don't doubt for a second it will not disappoint. If you're not a Mass Effect fan, now it's time to become one.

content:
26
 An exciting Space Adventure  9.3/10Now I know this game is quite old, but I have finally been able to sit and dive into the deep space of Mass effect. From the vast amount of planets to explore, to the commanding of my squad to take on the ventures unknown, I had one heck of a time.In the beginning I jumped in being prepared to get through the game as quickly as possible. Now it is not the best way to play this game, even though I had that mindset, I found myself veering off course to the different side quests the universe had to offer. Right from the start, you are given a variety of choices in dialogue in which molded your character with the personality you wanted to give. Now being the person I am I will always be the that knight in shining armour, but the choices were still very hard to choose from, sacrificing others for the good of mankind, or maybe saving a whole species but risking another catastrophe of war, it was a very hard decision.Putting aside the dialogue for a moment, there was still a lot of decision making when it came to the combat. Different weapons, with different upgrades and stats, then choosing if to keep the best weapon for yourself (of course you do) or giving it to your squad members. I have to admit I did spend a lot of time deciding which upgrades were best on which guns to make certain situations easier for me, some bullets did better against synthetics while others organics, and at the time of the fight you could just decide by thinking  Which enemy have I came across the most? Im not saying this a life or death decision but it really. REALLY. helped in some such situations but yeah I like combat to go smoothly when Im involved.Overall this game is a must play. I would advise getting it for the cheap price it is now than the full retail price it once was.

												Overall, good game, but since it's a bit older, don't expect inovation. A must play if you want to play the whole trilogy. Since it is an rpg, some of the missions will be frustrating beacause of difficulty (not the story related - they are scaled well, maybe a bit too easy. If you get into the game and story, the trilogy will reward you handsomly for your choices. There's a great feeling when you run into an old friend from previous game (s) - for example: meeting Wrex again in ME2.If you want to make progress in paragon/renegade system, immediatelly invest in charm/intimidate as the game will open these dialog options ONLY if you invest in them, not like in ME 2 & 3.One more VERY IMPORTANT INFORMATION: If your gameplay lags a lot and you get very low fps altho you have a machine that's way beyond minimum specs, try disabling your firewall. It helped me to play this game as it was supposed to be played 60+fpsEnjoy :)

content:
18, 2015
												Join Commander Shepard and his/her crew of humans and aliens to save the galaxy from a galactic threat. It's a Third-Person RPG Shooter that vaguely feels like Deus Ex at first, because weapons are fairly inaccurate to start with, and Shepard doesn't want to take a diazepam because your arms sway all over the damn place while trying to aim with a sniper. But soon you specialize in what weapon you think you're best with after killing enemies, completing quests, etc. with skill points you earn as you level up, as well as other misc passive & active abilities. Shepard's crew on the other hand, often come with biotic and tech abilities to help you in battle, and even in things like hacking devices.The weapons also work on an overheating system, as in they have unlimited ammo, but if you don't control your bursts well enough, they will overheat and you will be unable to use them for several seconds. There are weapon mods to reduce heat weapons produce, as well as other useful things, and ammo mods to inflict more damage, bypass shields, poison, etc.Along your quest, you can choose to either be a saintly paragon, or a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, or somewhere in between with the whole moral choice system, and the more you use the charm or intimidate options in dialog, the more levels you unlock in the charm/intimidate skill tree in which to spend your skill points in and unlock more dialog options.Then there's the epic world map of the galaxy, in which you can continue your main quest, or pull an Elder Scrolls and do ungodly amounts of sidequesting and explore everywhere. Usually when you land a on planet, you do so with a space buggy called the Mako, which is equipped with thrusters, a machine gun, and a cannon. You explore a fairly large surface area of the planets you land on, optionally collecting things such as veins and salvage to earn exp and money. Then there's the main point of the planet, which usually involves entering a facility, or cave, or just wipeing out a camp of hostiles.You collect lots of weapons, armors, weapon mods & ammo mods, along your way, which are magically transferred to your inventory after killing enemies, then theres a bunch of shops to buy and sell from. By the end of the game, I had several million credits, and 2 weapon mods to prevent overheating to the point where my weapons never overheated, I love when older RPGs do broken stuff like that.The main things I hate about the game are the sound glitches, and my CPU fan going ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at all times due to the game being punishing on your CPU. But thats just some technical problems, it's a great game and it runs fine besides that, I only ever crashed once.You can also import your save into the sequel, Mass Effect 2, and have a bunch of story elements impacted, as well as start with some bonus stuff. More games like this need to do that.

												One of the best games ever. Period.The story, the world, the history - everything is so well written and executed. There is a lot of backstory in this game and if you take time to read/listen to everything - you are going to enjoy every single second of Mass Effect and you will remember this game for many many years.I just finished my second playthrough (the first one was 4 years ago). Mass Effect doesn't age. it's still beautiful even after 9 years of its release.There are a few things that can be a pain in the ♥♥♥ (like driving a Mako through a rocky terrain or repetitive level design of facilities on different planets), but apart from that - it's a gem in every aspect. The developers have done a great job at making every planet look different. The skies are just beautiful (with so many stars and planets). Eh. Love it.Mass Effect is one of those games where you feel sad after finishing it.

content:
1, 2016
												Not much playtime yet on steam but I've played quite a lot on PS3 (90 hours or so) and the steam version is like that but with better graphics, fps, and loading times.It's a great sci-fi game and it's filled with a lot of exploration, backstory, and lore.The rpg elements are ok-ish and the combat's not polished compared to newer games, but the shooting is serviceable, not absolutely horrible. Just not up to today's standards I'd say.It's more star trek than any star trek game, because you get to be captain of a ship, make decisions that impact storylines and your relationship with your crew, pursue romantic interests, and explore plenty of planets (though admittedly they are sometimes kinda empty and the buildings are reused very often). And if you really like lore and backstories in your games, this game has plenty and a lot of them are fully voiced. What mass effect really does well is immersing you into its world.Would definitely recommend this game to anyone even remotely interested in sci fi.

content:
2, 2015
												After playing Dragon Age for a bit some years ago (I don't know why I quit? I had better things to do I guess) I decided to try out another infamous title from Bioware: Mass Effect. I had no idea what to expect and just went in blank. I entered a world full of Turians, Salarians, and a lot of other races I was quite sure I would never remember. But as the game progressed, I became quite fond of Turians. I met my first Volus along the way. I learned what a Specter was and what was expected of me when I became one. And the conversations. I love the conversations. Instead of watching a scene and waiting until you can play again, you decide how this conversation will end! Will your persuade your teammate to cooperate or will they leave you when you decide to yell at them? It's your decision.This is a game I'll never forget, and I'll make sure to give Dragon Age another go!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
4, 2012
												After seeing snippets of Mass Effect 2, I knew I had to play from the beginning. This game is a great start to this three part space opera. The story is deceptively simple. You are Commander Shephard and you must save the galaxy. As you complete the simple story you will have to make decisions that will flesh out the story and in some ways decide on who lives and who dies. Apart from the main story, there are numerous side missions that help develop relationships with fellow characters or influence what happens in the sequels. There is tons of replay value due to the fact that there are different ways to handle various situations in the game. The graphics have aged well, I think. The characters are all memorable. You won't like these characters, you will LOVE them. The relationships you build (or tear down) will follow you in the games to come. Now for the negatives, and I had to squint to see them. I personally found the exploration tedious. The planets you go to are all very detailed, with descriptions about their resources and history, but driving the vehicle to go through some of the rough terrain got to be annoying at times. Thats really the only negative I could think of. A great game that should be tried by everybody.

content:
er 19, 2016
												This is where it all started.I have hundreds of hours logged in this trilogy, both on Steam and on Origin  where I inevitably ported my Mass Effect 2 save files to, but I'll explain in my review of that  and I'm still not done with this series, and with its characters. Mass Effect means a lot to me, both as a game and as a story.The controls can be janky - especially if you're playing as an Infiltrator - and you'll quickly find yourself watching the same npc animations over and over as you progress through the game that's something that Bioware is quite infamous for, you'll find it in pretty much all of their games but as you immerse yourself in the story it all becomes superficial.There's so much you can do in this game, including optional quests that have impact on the story in the sequels (nothing too substantial unfortunately, they're more like easter eggs/cameos, but still nice to get nonetheless). I did a completionist run a few months back with my first male Shepard Uriel, and it was well worth the time and energy I put into it - though I wouldn't reccomend it for a first time player. Mass Effect has its flaws, both in its story and in its gameplay. But there's no denying that it's a classic, and that its beloved by a lot of people, including myself. It's worth it, trust me.

												The first Mass Effect game is a game that changed my life. It got me into astronomy and not many games will get me interested into a specific subject and will make me enjoy it. content:
2016
												Mass Effect has one of the best sci-fi stories out there and the universe is fascinating. The soundtrack is  absolutly beautiful. I love how the game gives you multiple options when dealing with other characters. Some guy is bothering you? You can politely ask him to go away, or deck him in the face- the choice is up to you. You can easily play this game 2-4 times and have very different experiences. Some cons:-Managing your inventory is way too tedious.-Elevator rides take forever to go anywhere and are completely pointless. Far too often I've gotten into an elevator, waited for the loading screen to being the elevator sequence, gone down the elevator, then waited again once the doors opened to load the map. Why??? It seems like a small thing, but man is it ever annoying (although elevator conversations amongst your sqadamates can be pretty entertaining).

content:
r 11, 2016
												The only reason to play this is for the story.Many of the reviews on this game lead you to believe is a nearly perfect game. That is probably out of love for most of the franchise and/or nostalgia. graphics are not "slightly dated" but extremely dated. combat is extremely clunky until you get to higher levels, and some fights on higher difficulties are damn near impossible. ie, battlemaster krogan. if you cant stun him, after he 1 shots your companions, he will charge you, and no matter how far you run he will wind up right behind you, then punch you and you're dead. There is also the fact that if you die on a boss, you are almost guaranteed to have to go through that entire cutscene again. same with any fight that has a cutscene.The gui is clunky, with stats not being clear, everything being fairly basic design.Planets are barren, with a few spots to visit. The mako is extremely weird to controll. often times you turn much more than you wanted too, it's fairly inaccurate when shooting unless you zoom in, which leaves you with no idea where you're pointing.if you want to play the mass effect series, go ahead and get this game, but don't expect a game with amazing mechanics.  If I knew what this game was like before, I probably would have just watched the story on youtube and saved myself a lot of time then moved on to play the last 2.

content:
, 2015
												11/10This is my favorite series of all time as far as RPG's go and almost one of my favorite period. However, it is a little dated looking now, so.. here is something to help with that.(For actual review skip to HERE! typed below)http://www.moddb.com/mods/mass-effect-1-new-texture-updatesimprovements-modCheck out that site, it will have you up and running with far improved shaders and graphics. Also, DLC!http://help.ea.com/en/article/mass-effect-bring-down-the-sky-dlc-redemption/In order to get the end DLC PS you will need to register your key with Origin. I hear rumor that it's automatically included with the game now and no longer a need to get the trillogy. I can't confirm this though. as I always move my back up file that contains the DLC I got wayyy back before EA nuked every available link for it... So I import my back up copy. You wont miss anything without the PS DLC as it's a very short run, and doesn't transfer anything to the next game. Bringing Down The Sky however is fantastic and I highly recomend it. Make sure to launch the game once before trying to install it. I have far more hours in this game than STEAM reports, as I had been playing it long before they started keeping track, and now play it through Origin since steam doesn't get updates for the series to keep them working with PhysX. (Political battle with EA I'm sure...) I'm sure there are ways to make it work with steam but I guess the launcher for the game isn't that big of a deal. I just launch Origin as a non steam game to keep the overlay.Read this, it might save you a lot of problem solving and head scratchinghttp://www.reddit.com/r/masseffect/comments/2uxq1r/problem_installing_meuitm_for_me1/Still need more? Here you gohttp://forum.bioware.com/topic/215916-making-the-most-of-your-me1-pc-experience-maximizing-graphics-and-sound/HERE!Mass Effect is a sci fi RPG set in the future. You travel between galexies trying to save the univers from a massive threat.The choices you make matter. People will live or die because of them, some choices you wont even see the results from until you are playing the second or third game. You truely shape your own story and it's fantastic in every way. The game play mechanics are a bit dated, as are the graphics but the mod listed above should help with the later. While the game play mechanics are dated, they aren't lacking in fun. They aren't tedius, they just aren't stream lined. ME2 has a change in this, and 3 alters game play even further. In this installment you have a inventory and can buy different weapons, armor, ammo types, and get some resonable depth with the leveling system. The next installments simplify this and you lose a lot of that old style mechanic. (I like the armor system and weapon system a lot in the first game but the ways to improve in the second game are good  as well, just different.) You work as a squad, and command each member. That beind said they do have AI and work on their own as well. You can choose to let them use their powers by themselves or, to have complete control of what they use and when they use it by issuing commands. You get to explore planets, there might be random people trying to fight out for their lives, giant creatures waiting to kill you, or little monkeys stealing tech you really want to get your hands on. There is so much I would like to say, but won't at risk of spoiling the adventure for you. Get out there, suit up, and have some fun.If you are going to play any of these games, I highly suggest starting with this one and playing all the way through. If you don't, there are things you will miss. Big things, and little things that make the series shine so bright. I'm commander Lex Lagger, and this is my favorite game on steam. (You'll get the joke once you get to ME2)

content:
2015
												No one likes to display their closet nerd stuff out in public.There are only about 4 types of game related shirts I come across that people seem okay with wearing out into public without getting massive wedgies from everyone. Halo or Call of Duty something (shooter nerds trying to act like they're not nerds chugging all that Mountain Dew) A Horde or Alliance symbol (Warcraft nerds) Anything Nintendo related (Nintendo's cool but Super Smash Brothers on Steam is the future come on Reggie Fils make it happen...) The mysterious N7 symbol (You'll see well groomed, attractive, a-list type folks whom you're sure couldn't possibly be into games strutting around in these)Yes, the N7 symbol that comes from Mass Effect.  People walk around wearing this in real life with beaming pride.  The amount of respect for the symbolic designation of Commander Sheppard's training in interplanetary warfare (The N7 ranking) is huge amongst fans.  The distribution of Commander Sheppard's Jersey (N7) may very well rival the amount of wear and public exposure as some semi-popular professional athelete jerseys.Mass Effect is here to stay...indefinitely.  With this first game a giant amount of gamers became life long fans.  It's amazing to see the sheer diversity of people who have become so attached to the universe and the characters.  People cosplay the characters and go to conventions even though the trilogy for Mass Effect has reached its conclusion long ago.  (No worries, there are definitely more Mass Effect games to come).Along with Dragon Age, Baldur's Gate and Knights of the Old Republic, this would be another example of Bioware's dedication to crafting intense stories and deep characters that people can really dive deep into.The GameMass Effect is a Space RPG focused on story and character development.  The conversation wheel is used frequently to allow the character to engage in discussions with other NPCs and teammates they encounter during gameplay.In this game you play as the commander of an elite team consisting of the galaxy's most skilled interstellar fighters in a mission to save the galaxy.  It's essentially a third person, cover shooter where you can issue commands to your teammates to strategically position them and to use special abilities on enemies.You can fight with what is essentially Star Wars-esque Force PowersAlong with all manner of space guns: Rifles, Sniper Rifles, Pistols, Shotguns, automatics and so on.Pros Great Gameplay mechanics Excellent Story Excellent Character Design (People are obsessed with their favorite characters) Excellent Visuals Very elaborate RPG elements Choices made can impact the of outcome events both immediately and in later games (This is the first part of a trilogy)Cons Inventory can get a little cluttered There's a rare chance that you can encounter a catastrophic bug in a few places that will prevent you from progressing (must reload your last save) Save Often The entire trilogy isn't available on Steam....blame Electronic Arts.If you enjoy Sci Fi and RPGs, this game is a no brainer.  You've probably played it already.  If you haven't...now's the time...

content:
9, 2014
												Excelent and very involving. The game offers you a rich scenario, with plenty of things to do. The game mechanics are a bit unconfortable, but it gets fun once you get used to it. Soundtrack is beautiful and well suited, the plot is very well designed, involving and fun to uncover. The graphics are old, but they are good enough. Characteres are the main strength of the game I think: very complex personalities, many possible interactions and dialogue outcomes. You will never few like you are talking to the same NPC, regardeless if he is a shopper, guard, squad member or quest-NPC. They are so well design you can few pity or foundness for some of them.The game have weaknesses , I can say that for one thing, money is useless. Yes, you can buy some interesting upgrades and weapons/armors with it. But it is definitely not a must, you can go just fine with the loots you find in mission. The few upgrades you can't find in mission (like extra medi-gel capacity for instance) are so cheap it doesen't really few you are spending anything. Speaking of upgrades, those are another weak spot of the game. Too many of those and they don't look so different. When you less expect you will be carrying too many of those and not knowing good combinations. I also expected some spaceship warefare...but the game has none. The character role I picked has also some kind of a problem. As an infiltrator, the best combat strategy I have has to sniper-shoot everyone...and cry if an enemy get to close, since I don't have any other effective trained weapon to use. One would expect some sort of clock ability - they fixed that in ME 2, fortunately.But those are minor weaknesses. I would score the game 4 out of 5.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 16, 2014
												Oh Mass Effect, such nostalgia, much wow. It's been nearly 8 years since the initial launch of Bioware's Space Epic and to this day the industry is still learning from it. Mass Effect 2 brought serious improvements to the ME universe however the original Mass Effect is a classic. The Morality system where a player could either become a Paragon (Good) or a Renegade (Bad) was similar to the likes of the Good and Evil system of games like Fable however it actually awarded the player with satisfaction. Every decision point actually effected how you played the game.The planet exploration system in Mass Effect has and always will be amazing, roaming planets with the Mako Rover was fun but awkward at times due to the mechanics however this was improved vastly in Mass Effect 2. When using the Mass Relay system to teleport from one relay to another you would get a decent animation that was followed by a stunning central planet followed by it's surrounding plants. The galaxy's that filled the space in between were stunning as well, with a high fidelity of stars and more it was a sight for the eyes that I have not forgotten to this day.Actual combat was fairly decent however again it was vastly improved in Mass Effect 2. If you ever need a great game or series to play, something you plan to put at least a hundred plus hours into, the Mass Effect trilogy is a great choice however I suggest you prepare yourself for the ending of Mass Effect 3, don't say I didn't warn you about that one. If this game's on sale for $4.99 or even $19.99 BUY IT and the other two Mass Effect games as well (Mass Effect 3 is only available on Origin sadly, thanks EA).

												Mass Effect is a must have.Simply because it kicked off the most sophisticated Sci-Fi IP of the past 30 years. The richness and depth of the Mass Effect Series' universe is easily on par with Star Wars and Star Trek. If you are a Sci-Fi Fan you can not help but get sucked in and swallowed whole by this beast.As a game the strength of Mass Effect besides it's lore is a superb story within that lore, believable Charaters to interact with, choices over choices that impact not only the current game but reach forward into part 3 and some of the best written and performed dialog of all time.Within the series this is the game featuring the most Exploration opportunities and the strongest classical RPG elements (VERY stat and skill dependant down to a limit in inventory space, lots of loot).The weak points:Bugs. It's a problem with the whole series. There is nothing gamebreaking, but some Bugs are just plain out annoying and stupid but never got fixed. My guess is that this is in no small part due to the fact that the Mass Effect games are made for consoles first and foremost and are from a console era when patching wasn't really an option.While the Exploration possibilities are quite big it sadly isn't done very well. Most of it consists of driving a vehicle with crazy physics through randomly generated height maps that had a few prefabs placed in them. That is litterally something that a hobbyist just learning how to make maps can put together in an hours work or less.The list of weak points could be made longer.But in reality they do not matter. Because the story and how it is presented not only makes up for the weak points. It lets you forget them. I am just in the middle of another series playthrough just because I have finally gotten all DLCs for part 3. And this probably is the strongest pro going for the series: Even though you could play just part 3. When you pick it up again you wanna start at the beginning again. With Part 1. Because seeing a new Shepard evolve and change over the course of three games is just awesome. It is just like those Lord of the Ring or Star Wars weekends when you watch all the movies in succession. Only better because it lasts for weeks. Hell a 100% completion playthrough of all three games is worth easily 150 hours of playtime.Last but not Least: Another important reason to get the Mass Effect Series is that part 4 is rumored to hit us next year at the latest and you absolutely will want to know what all the fuss is about when that happens.

content:
29, 2014
												This game is very near to perfect. If you like RPG, this will quite literally give you a galaxy's worth of role playing. I'll start with the things that don't matter hugely to an RPG, but add to it and bring it to perfection. Firstly, the graphics are beautiful. Individually, tree leaves may look a little pixelated, and close-up shots of weaponry and armour suffer the same effect. However, when the graphics are bought together as a whole the effect is simply profound. Vast cityscapes sprawl beneath the viewing deck on the Citadel's wards, amazing scenery from the Presidium. All the skyboxes are filled with amazing imagery; binary star systems, meteorite showers, even simply beautiful blue skies and white clouds. Tying it all together are the little graphic effects, such as the lifelike water, or whisps of smoke and steam. Detailing on the characters, aliens, and animals are all done excelently, making the alien species not only believable, but also emotionally telling even when blue or scaley. Add to this very effective use of lighting and colours, and the option to have a 'film grain' graphics setting, and you are left with a game that is just beautiful.Next, the music and sounds on this game are very well suited to the gameplay. As with most RPGs, the music seems to crescendo with each new adventure or battle, however at points in this game it also brings in much more somber and melancholly sounding music to reflect the emotions of the charecters and crew aboard the Normandy. In either case, the music always seems to reflect the fact that this is a game anbout space, and definitely adds to the other-worldly feel. The sound effects in the game are not necessarilly subtle, however when playing they become absorbed into the gameplay, something which personally I applaud. All to often I find myself turning down the sound effect volume on a game for it being to loud, or doing the complete opposite as it's too quiet to hear an enemy right behind you. With Mass Effect, all of the sounds effects are well designed so that they fit perfectly into context, and are never out of place. The voice acting in this game is spot on, all the characters are capable of so much emotion, and make the game so much more believable than counterparts with lesser vocals. Even alien races have voices to match, and a variety within the races at that, rather than the same voice actor for every member of a species (Skyrim, guards, what?). Gameplay moves fluidly, whith characters interacting very well with the environment. I don't think I ever found a character floating in mid air, or stuck inside a boulder or staircase, or limbs from a character on one side of a door potruding through to the other side. Charecters take cover when commanded, are able to peer and shoot around objects, and team commands work excelently when directed, and still work well when on automatic. Customisation of you and your team's loadout was most definitely confusing at first, however once grasped really gave the combat situations an extra tactical element, allowing choices between weapons and ammunition types for each new enemy encountered. Added to the game is a hacking minigame which allows you to unlock doors, crates and safes, and this increases with difficulty as it increases with reward, however it would have been nice for the developers to add other methods of hacking - I doubt all locks in the galaxy use the exact same system. Effectively the game has 3 levels of gameplay, the most important being on foot, secondly missions involving driving the mako, and lastly small elements from being in orbit. When in orbit you are free to walk around and interact with your spaceship, and have access to the galaxy map. From this map you can explore the galaxy through nebulas, star systems and down to an individual planetary level. This allows you to scan planets for resources, and choose to land on some of the planets to perform a mission. When on minor missions on other planets, usually you will be assigned to drive the mako, an armoured six wheeled heavy hitting tank of sorts. Equiped with some form of machine gun, a slower firing cannon, and the ability to fly for a very brief period of time, it is fun to use. The controls are a bit strange at first, with the turning not behaving quite as you'd expect, however once you've gotten used to it, the driving becomes a lot more fun.Finally, the part most people want from an RPG to be perfect is the story, the character interactions, quite simply, the role playing. This game SATISFIES. In playing this game you can either simply blast through the main missions and skip the dialogue, missing out the majority of the context and background, or you can take the time to talk to minor characters, pick up side missions, and simply use dialogue options to ask questions. All of these actions add a hugely deep and mixed background for the in-game galaxy, with complex interactions and repercussions of past actions echoed in the game you get to play, although possibly misunderstood or simply missed if the player choses to ignore them. If the interactions themselves didn't satisfy, the game has a 'codex', which is basically an encyclopedia which fills as you play and interact, meaning that if at any point you forget something you've picked up or simply want to learn more about an aspect of the game (with a large scope, from biology and cuture of alien races, to the weapons and armour used on the Normandy) you can delve into the codex and gain a better understanding. The storyline is believable, and multiple storylines can be followed through the use of paragon (hero) or renegade (badass) options. This allows for much greater depth and character development, and continues with your choices in the first game bridging over into the sequels. The paragon/renegade choice also shapes the way you interact with individual characters, bringing different methods of conflict resolution, persuading your way through tough situations, or even romance with the choice being left to the player. Character interactions are usually emotionally charged without being unreal, and these emotions build as you become closer to your crew, leading to some very hard decisions in the late game. Overall, this is one of my most favourite games I've ever played since I started on a Windows 95 at the age of 2. I fell in love on my first playthrough, and it definitely brings an amazing sense of gravitas with it. The game is deep, moving, and most importantly believable. Grapics, audio, and gameplay elements tie the whole package together in a beautiful way, and pull the player in deeper. I'd easilly give this a 9/10, and would recomend this to anyone with even a slight love of RPG. Simply put, buy this game, play it, and cherish it.

r 24, 2011
												Belated review. If you are a sucker for any of the following: spaceships, aliens, storytelling, RPGs, shooters, or sci-fi in general, and haven't yet played Mass Effect... well, what are you waiting for?!? Even though it's a few years old now and has a few minor problems, Mass Effect is still well-worth playing, especially if you have any interest at all in the upcoming ME3. I thought overall it was a really fun game, especially the story aspects. The shooting mechanics are also perfectly fine. The only major gripe I had was the weapon/inventory system. Throughout your journey, you are constantly finding tons of weapons and upgrades, 99% of which are duplicates or unneccessary. The interface for managing weapons is also confusing and cumbersome. But that one thing aside, I pretty much loved everything else about ME1. If you haven't played it yet, get it now!

												Mass Effect is a sexual rollercoaster. One minute, your ♥♥♥♥ is starting to tremble from the adrenaline that you feel as you're slaughtering dozens of unarmed colonists, the next you're getting rammed by a Krogan warlord. And nothing quite prepares you for the initial feeling of going balls deep in an Asari scientist, as you pull on her ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little tentacles. And lemme tell ya, this octopus doesn't trim her garden (Geddit?! Pubic hair comments with Beatles references!) However, the most powerful experience this game gives the player is the possibility to take advantage of an Easter egg in which you can anally probe a Geth, which shows how hard the developers worked to hold true to their sci-fi roots. Remember when that movie "AI. Artificial Intelligence" with Jude Law came out back in 2001, and everyone wanted to bang the brains out of Haley Joel Osment's character? It's kinda like that, but without the pedo vibe. All in all, I give Mass Effect 11 ♥♥♥♥♥♥ tentacles out of 5. Meaning it was "meh."

												BioWare are masters at world building, and in this case universe building. Mass Effect is a massive sci-fi experience, letting the player explore an entire galaxy while offering superb characters and storytelling. It's true that the action is somewhat simplistic, and experienced players will rarely be threatened, but the whole thing is so stunningly beautiful and epic that you won't care. Honestly, I really thought there was no chance that Bioshock would be challenged for game of 2007, but Mass Effect equals it for sheer cinematic awesomeness. Compulsory gaming!

												This is my first review so please don't hate!Mass Effect 1 is the first of the ME trilogy, one of the best RPG trilogies of today.Despite lacking the better graphics of the later 2 games, the story is still extreemly well made, the characters are just amazing to play, talk and experiment with, lots of quest and places to explore (for those who love completing the games as much as possible and have the patience to do it)Unfortunately it still has some bugs in it, but most people have found ways around them if you look around for fixes, at least i managed to fix 2-3 more known bugs such as the sound crackle, starmap bug and quicksave bug.It is one of my favorite games of all time, Bioware has the most talented dev's from my point of view so bear with the graphics and play your way trough this trilogy, its well worth every single penny.

content:
y 1, 2016
												I really enjoyed this gamePros--The story is well crafted and you can tell alot of effort was put into it. It has lots of twists, turns, and reveals that are pretty good. Not mind blowing, but still, its one of the highlights of the game. Theres alot there if you want to dig giving players a choice in how far they want to go into the lore of the worle. -Interactions with your squad members are memorable and personal. Each has distinct personalities and underlying motives that are there if you spend the time to get to know them all-The branching diolauge paths are great. Give some depth and a player's touch into the game. Not super deep and many diolauges still lead to the exact same result but thats ok.-The settings were pretty good. It was really neat to go explore all these planets and choose in what order you were to do it in. The aliens and universe created here are also interesting and thought out.-Runs well on my crap PC and also has a widespread texture mod for those who seek higher fidelity. Cons-Elevators. There are alot of them. Most I assume are disgusing loading screens and it really gets old fast especially when in some situations you go through one elevator, get out, walk a bit, then go up another. -Combat. While it is good I wouldnt call it great. I played on the hardest difficulty with AI actions turned off for my squad mates and one of two things would happen in combat situations: my main character could just wipe out all the enemies without the help of my squadmates so I have no reason to even have them do anything, or when I do need them they are HORRIBLE at staying alive. Even when you direct them towards cover they very often come out for no reason and die. Somtimes you plan a combo of abilities on a enemy all at once but one squad member decides that its just not happening today. It got annoying. Also I didnt like that you had to pick your squadmates from the begining of the mission when you have no idea whats in store. They all have different abilities but only a few combos cover everything so it locks you out of doing certain combos of characters you may like. Overall it is an ok combat system, that with some tweaks could be really really good.-Driving sections - controls are kind of slippery and every driving section all game has the same 3 or 4 enemies making them really easy and really boring-Enemies. There are only about 10 enemys in the whole game if you dont count reskins. Kind of a a let down. -Final Boss- Ended up just being the main bad guy with the abilities of one of the enemy types you have fought all game with a stupid amount of health and rocket launchers added on. I get that the combat doesnt really lend itself to grandiose boss battles but still. Boss battles in general were usually just waves of common enemies. -Save points, This is the grandaddy of my annoyances with this game. Probably 5-10 times thoughout the main game you will have boss battles or very difficult encounters that have loooong cutscenes or elevators right before them. These cannot be skipped and its awful. Every time you die you have to walk through the same diolauge for 2 minutes before you fight. It gets old really fast espeicailly if you are having a real tough time with the boss. I get not skipping on the first time but there is no reason you shouldnt be able to skip on subsequent viewings.Overall I did really enjoy this game. This is a game that is greater than the sum of its parts. It keep me wanting to play to figure out what would happen next which cant be said for too many games I play. If you like a good space story and third person tactical shooters, I would grab this game. 7.5/10
