												If you're looking to play this game then buckle up, kiddo, you're in for a ride.Experience the beginning of the epic journey with your custom or default Commander Shepard with a gender of your choice.Get sucked into a huge universe so full of lore, that three games wasn't enough to fit it all in, no, there's books (three worth mentioning and one worth forgetting) and comics and even a movie. AND there's another game coming next year, how great is that?Explore a vast galaxy with numerous planets to land on in a huge number of clusters.Freeze your lovely behind off on Noveria, jump the Mako over pits of Lava on Therum or stomp Geth with them (the Mako rocks, I don't care what anybody says), enjoy the scenery on Virmire (because that's the only thing you'll be enjoying there) and get lost on Ilos (every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time).Find loyal companions to fight by your side and befriend them. Maybe even smooch them if you feel that way. You can even smooch non-humans. Or not. Have it your way, really, this game is all about your choices and how they affect all the living beings in the galaxy.Make choices that affect everyone. Make choices that seem minute to you but grow monstrously in size and come back to bite you in your lovely behind later. Make choices that might kill people you know.Prepare for the biggest fight of your life.Be brave, be badass, be bad at dancing, be Commander Shepard.And after you're done? Well there's still two more games for you to question your choices, cry a lot (this is not optional) and start a new playthrough because you didn't need your heart intact anyway.

content:
13, 2016
												Very good Sci-fi RPG.You choose a class and level your characters like any other RPG game, but the combat is a real-time 3rd person shooter. Building and strengthing your character is just as important as your ability to dodge enemy fire, use cover, and score headshots for critical damage. The game also has different difficulties settings to choose from in case you need to lower it. You also have 2 teammates with you at any given time.Aside from combat; you can literally spend hours at a time just going around exploring, talking to people, and reading codexes you come across (bits of information about certain guns or whatever). Some people love this stuff, others hate it, so its purely preference if you'll like it or not. The main highlight of this game though is the option to choose your own path/dialogue. You can pretty much apologize to someone, agree to disagree, or sometimes just straight up punch them in their face. Then the next time you meet this person down the road, IF you meet them again, they'll remember how the previous conversation went and it affects the feel of the game. It might even open or close off certain things. The overall core storyline of the game is the same though, you can't change that. It's also a trilogy. Certain decisions you make can span from game 1 game into the next if you transfer save files.It's a well-made game for its genre (and an even better trilogy). So if you're not into these type of games (Sci-fi / shooter / Action RPG / deep storytelling with alot of decisions and information/lore) then you simply won't like it.Cons: A few times playing this game I had to load an older save file due to some weird glitches happening. Maybe 3 times in 50+ hours of playing. (only lost a total of 10 minutes of playtime or so). Other than that the game ran fine for me.

content:
ry 14
												I picked this up during the X-mas sale and only recently installed it. I generally don't play shooters, but Mass Effect has a healthy dose of searching and exploring and story. I've always played "lurkers" in games, rather kill from the shadows. }:>I chose the Infiltrator class (I know, my friends are totally shocked) even though I read from several sources that the sniper rifle was a pain to master. It is a pain, but I can live with that. Took me more than a few occasions to unlearn that the spacebar does not make you jump... probable the only thing that bothers me so far. Because when I explore I like to jump and climb on things. I'm enjoying it very much so far at least I would hope so considering that I logged 6.6 hours on my first night of playing. :)So yeah, I'd recommend it.PS: sinewav put up a nice beginner's guide that explains the classes pretty well and what he considers their strengths and weaknesses, recommendations on how difficult newbs might find each class, on the crew you should pair up with them to fill in the holes. And I think he did a good job of it without filling it with spoilers. You can find it here: 


Guide for New Mass Effect Players 
A Guide for Mass Effect
By: sinewav

			This guide will provide tips and first hand experience on how to have the best experience playing Mass Effect 1. I will also address how to best mold your character for ME2 and ME3 without providing any spoilers.		


EDIT:  Since I have a relatively new machine, ME wouldn't even launch on first attempt, a quick search will reveal 2 things that can solve this: Set the .exe to run in Admin mode and to download a legacy Nvidia driver. The first one worked for me.

content:
y 5
												This one had the best gameplay in the series in my opinion. Probably going to get lynched for saying that but it's true. This is the only Mass Effect that is actually an RPG. They managed to make a super awesome shooter RPG with 6 different classes and an adequately complex levelling system and inventory management. And for Mass Effect 2 they threw all of that out the window, removed the whole inventory thing completely and made the levelling system the simplest any RPG has ever had, which is why I hesitate to call Mass Effect 2 or 3 an RPG.This one also has the best story, and so it's pretty much better than Mass Effect 2 and 3 in every way, except for graphics. 10/10 best Mass Effect game to date, fingers crossed for Andromeda.

content:
ry 5, 2016
												Wow. What a fantastic experience this game was.I've heard so much about this game before actually getting myself to finally play it. Mainly because I'm not a fan of SCI-FI or shooter. Well I wasn't, before I started Mass Effect. This game is incredible. It will drag you in with it's fantastic gameplay, brilliantly written story with massive lore, amazing character development, beautiful music, beautiful landscapes, unique atmosphere, masterfully done voice acting and some of what are probably one of the most memorable characters in the game history. This is one of the rare games I actually finished. I have the tendency to play too many things at once to focus on a single game alone. This game, however, was an exception and getting it was probably one of the best decisions I've made in my life. I got it on sales for an € or so, but it is not only worth it's original price, but double that. I recommend this game to everyone everywhere that cherishes brilliant dialogues, deep character development, huge lore behind the main story, for people that don't want to just walk straight forward and shoot stuff, but for people that enjoy exploring the world they are in, for people that enjoy making decisions and think logically. Truly a masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2015
												I just got this for a couple of bucks, and after not playing it for several years, I got to say that this game has aged quite well in my opinion. For today's standards (regarding graphics and whatnot), it still holds up, and has some pretty good visuals. They do look a bit dated, of course, but for a game originally released in 2007, it looks great. Several people have complained about the Mako (driving) sections, and while the controls are a bit wonky, it still is a good idea, and it's not as bad as most people make it sound. And now,  let's talk about the heart of this game, and what makes it so special; the expanding, interesting, epic and completely immersive story filled with fully fleshed characters that you care about, amazing plot-twists, and an open ended narrative. This is what makes the ME series so special, along with it's bigger-than life space opera setting. Finally, I have to say that this game is a bargain. It offers at least 30 hours of gameplay, and if you explore every little corner and do every single side quests, those 30 hours could easily stretch to 50. Get this thing ASAP.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 18, 2013
												2007 was a golden year for gaming.  With titles like Bioshock and Super Mario Galaxy, it was undoubtedly a great year.  Mass Effect is one of those rare few games that truely capture what an RPG is all about.  Combining fantastic writing, visuals that still hold up to this day, a combat system that was so different yet worked so well, and a giant open world, you have one hell of a game.  RPG elements include skill leveling, tons of different kinds of weapons, abilities that all serve a purpose in the battlefield, and tons of side quests (some goofy, some awesome) that all seem to work so well.  The characters are colorful and the voice acting superb, especially Jennifer Hale's femshep voice.  But remember, humans are not the only species in the galaxy, and aliens play a big part in your adventure, some will help you and some will try to kill you, so its up to you to decide who should pal around at your side.Of course, with all great things, there are downsides.  The world, as vast as it is, can seem a bit empty at times, and the squad memeber AI can prove to be difficult.  There are a few glitches, but nothing gamebreaking and nothing severely awful.All in all I reccomend this game to everyone, as it is one hell of a ride from beginning to end.  The truely unfortunate thing is that Mass Effect might have been BioWare's magnum opus, as the 2 sequels fell under the care of EA.  We can only hope BioWare has woken up to try and fix what they destroyed in Mass Effect 4.I give Mass Effect a 10/10

												If you're looking to play this game then buckle up, kiddo, you're in for a ride.Experience the beginning of the epic journey with your custom or default Commander Shepard with a gender of your choice.Get sucked into a huge universe so full of lore, that three games wasn't enough to fit it all in, no, there's books (three worth mentioning and one worth forgetting) and comics and even a movie. AND there's another game coming next year, how great is that?Explore a vast galaxy with numerous planets to land on in a huge number of clusters.Freeze your lovely behind off on Noveria, jump the Mako over pits of Lava on Therum or stomp Geth with them (the Mako rocks, I don't care what anybody says), enjoy the scenery on Virmire (because that's the only thing you'll be enjoying there) and get lost on Ilos (every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time).Find loyal companions to fight by your side and befriend them. Maybe even smooch them if you feel that way. You can even smooch non-humans. Or not. Have it your way, really, this game is all about your choices and how they affect all the living beings in the galaxy.Make choices that affect everyone. Make choices that seem minute to you but grow monstrously in size and come back to bite you in your lovely behind later. Make choices that might kill people you know.Prepare for the biggest fight of your life.Be brave, be badass, be bad at dancing, be Commander Shepard.And after you're done? Well there's still two more games for you to question your choices, cry a lot (this is not optional) and start a new playthrough because you didn't need your heart intact anyway.

												I picked this up during the X-mas sale and only recently installed it. I generally don't play shooters, but Mass Effect has a healthy dose of searching and exploring and story. I've always played "lurkers" in games, rather kill from the shadows. }:>I chose the Infiltrator class (I know, my friends are totally shocked) even though I read from several sources that the sniper rifle was a pain to master. I'm enjoying it very much so far at least I would hope so considering that I logged 6.6 hours on my first night of playing. :)So yeah, I'd recommend it.PS: sinewav put up a nice beginner's guide that explains the classes pretty well and what he considers their strengths and weaknesses, recommendations on how difficult newbs might find each class, on the crew you should pair up with them to fill in the holes. And I think he did a good job of it without filling it with spoilers. You can find it here: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=123753085EDIT:  Since I have a relatively new machine, ME wouldn't even launch on first attempt, a quick search will reveal 2 things that can solve this: Set the .exe to run in Admin mode and to download a legacy Nvidia driver. The first one worked for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2, 2015
One of the best modern story-driven RPG's I've ever played. I have no complaints about ME1. I loved every minute of my 2 playthroughs. On my 5yr old PC there were no graphic glitches, no lag or issues of any kind. Just smooth sailing graphics & a wonderful story. The characters are well-written, even the ones you don't like (looking at you Ashley). As in KOTOR, you can go Light or Dark, good or bad, making Dialog choices to reflect your own personality or how you want Commander Shepard to be perceived. In this game at least, your choices don't really affect the endgame outcome. Your choices DO open up different dialog options and some side quests. It adds fun flavor to the game.I loved finding all the armor & weps scattered around everywhere you go. I liked the hacking puzzle mini-game to open caches. It reminded me of the similar hydraulic puzzle game in Bioshock, which I also loved - both the main game & the mini puzzle game.The DLC is FreeAnother plus for ME1 is the 2 DLC's are free & easily found to download. Some nice people have already linked them in other helpful reviews, or just Google.Common ComplaintsThe MakoSome people complain about the Mako, which if you haven't played the game yet, is a tank-like vehicle you drive when you explore planets. I personally loved driving the crazy thing. Yes, it can be hard to control. Things can get a little wild, but it's really not that hard & once you get the hang of it, driving it literally anywhere is good fun. Mostly though, combat in the thing with its cannon & gun are a literal blast.ExplorationSome people complained about exploring Planets. I personally enjoyed this aspect as well. You only explore at most, 1 planet per system, & exploring each planet only takes a few minutes. Of course, I did really like driving the Mako so any excuse to get in the thing & go nuts was welcome.Game Won't Start, or get a Black or White Screen then game won't startThis did actually happen to me once, but is VERY simple to fix. Find the game's .exe, right click it and select "Open as Administrator". If that doesn't work for you, exit Steam, then Right-click Steam to "Open As", THEN rt click ME1's .exe to "Open As". You should only ever have to do this once, then done. It happened to me at about 5hours in. I was frustrated for about 10 minutes before I found this simple solution. After that I just started the game normally for the rest of my playtime.Other Similar Games I recommend you play:Dragon Age SeriesMass Effect SeriesKOTOR SeriesBioshock Series - Especially 1, 2 & Minerva's Den DLC (Excellent standalone story there)All of those game titles are equal in my esteem. They all provide good value for the price & all have a great story. These games all really draw you in. IMO you just can't go wrong with any of them.Comments About ME2 & 3(*Included here because many people are buying 1&2 here together)While ME1 had only 2 DLC, both of which are now free, ME2 & ME3 both have numerous expensive DLC that never goes on sale. In fact, you can't just "buy" & DL DLC for those 2 games. Nope. Even though you can purchase ME2 on Steam, you have to go to Origin to get the DLC for it.Of course some people needlessly complain about Origin, but truthfully, Origin is awesome. It's a very solid Game Management / Store Interface, just as good as Steam for it's own purposes.Anyway, say you buy the ME1/2 pack here on Steam & you want to then buy DLC for the game, which must be done on Origin (or also on social.bioware.com). ME2/Deluxe does come with a tiny bit of DLC, which you can also activate on Origin along with the base game, should you wish to. Simple steps are needed: Install the game in Steam Right-click ME2 in your Steam library and "View CD Key" (The game must be installed to have this option) Open Origin. If you didn't already, create an account & log in. At the top left, click on Origin, then click "Redeem Product Code" There are 3 codes for ME2. Copy each from the little Steam window, one at a time, then paste to Activate in the Origin app. Find the game in your Origin Library, hover the mouse over it then click the little italicized "i", which opens a more detailed Information page.On the Info page you can see a list of all the DLC, much of which is free. However, the good stuff, namely the Content packs which give you more missions & not just fluff cosmetics, cost money.Actually, they cost "Bioware Points". Yes, it's lame, but there's no way around it. BC although Bioware makes insanely awesome games, the guy in charge of setting up the sale of DLC is obviously a crackhead. There's simply no other explanation for why they think this is a good idea, as opposed to just being able to put all the desired DLC in your cart then buying it all straight up.Nope. You put what you want in the cart, then when you Checkout......it takes you to buy Bioware Points. 1600 Points sells for $20, 1200/$15 & 800/$10. It's very simple math to figure out which DLC you really want then convert the dollar value to how many Bioware Points you need. It's really very annoying, but it's not that complicated.You're going to need ~$40 for all the ME2 DLC. More for ME3. So, even though you probably only paid $20 for all 3 games (on sale of course), you're going to probably be forking out $80+ more dollars for any content & cosmetics you may want for ME2 & ME3.One last note. I hear that DLC you buy for ME2 (in Origin of course) can also be activated in your Steam copy of the game, though I don't see the need to do it, so I've never tried. I honeslty don't know why you wouldn't just play it in Origin. But it's said to be possible should you wish to try it.Hope this info was helpful. Enjoy!

												What can I say about Mass Effect? It is one of my all-time favorite games. The story is really good and the replay value is high due to the fact that you can create different characters focusing on different abilities. Want to be a soldier with all the toys of destruction or a full biotic with limited weapons, or a technician. You can play a character as these types and some in between.One of the greatest things about the Mass Effect trilogy is that you can import a completed game character into the next installment of the franchise and get bonuses for completing the last installment and pick your character up where you left off. You of course can always just start a new character as well, but it is the carryover of the character that makes the series really unique.The only strikes against it is some of the tedium related to exploring planets and inventory wrangling.Definitely a must buy.

content:
18, 2013
												I honestly wasn't expecting that this game was going to be as good as it really is. I believe I spent more time going through the codex and every single dialogue option other than the actual combat itself. The story in Mass Effect might feel to some the usual "bad aliens killing everyone in the galaxy" story but, in my opinion there's alot more to it. For me it was like reading a book, the soundtrack along with the cinematics really imerse you into the game. Of course that if you played Mass Effect before the second one and the third one came out, right after getting the ending you knew there will be a sequel. Now, about the combat, it might look and feel like a normal third person run 'n cover shooter but once you get a few hours into the game you'll find a very well polished and easy to use combat system along with squad commands. Some games fail to introduce "psychic" abilities in a way that it doesn't feel "paranormal", that's another thing I really liked about Mass Effect, the way they introduced biotics into the storyline feels "kinda authentic". The roleplaying aspect is really good, from the loot drops (which I believe these aren't random), to the skill "tree" that affects your abilities along the abilities of your fellow ones. The last roleplaying aspect that I really liked was that I think they really managed to pull off some really good "side effects" or more like consequences on the storyline depending on the dialogue options you choose, but my favourite one was with no doubt the one in which you had to decide to save Kaidan or Ashley on Virmire but there's also of course the one about going to bed either with Ashley or Liara. Also, I have to mention that there's TONS of side quests you might come across either when travelling in space or when wandering around the Citadel. The space exploration is kinda 'meh', it basicly is you going from star system to star system and just clicking on planets and scanning them for resources ocasionally finding some asteroids on the background. On the other hand I really liked the planet exploration when you drop on your Mako, going around the mountains and going to key locations, it's something out of the extraordinary but it was fun for me. There's also a "hack" mini-game that happens when you wish to unlock some crates or even recover some artifacts which is kinda appealing, it reminded me of Super Hexagon. I really regret not playing this earlier but I'm really glad I did buy it and finished it, an amazing mix of RPG with third person shooting that excels in pretty much any way if you ask me, I can safely say it is amongst the most engaging game worlds I've ever experienced, give it a try.

content:
y 6, 2016
												 For those of you who don't know, this is the first game of a trilogy.  It is set in the future, humanity has discovered on mars a great technology that came from well before our time.. by studying the find our scientist discover a great many new things and it accelorates humanity into the rest of the galaxy.. where we quickly do not make friends.  The game picks up with you as Commander Sheppard (character you create, male or female) being trained as part of an eliete group of operatives that polices (for lack of a better description) the galaxy. Combat for the game is fairly simple,  you have multiple weapons.  Unlimited ammo.. but all weapons over heat if they are fired too frequently keeping you from just spam firing all the time.  Each of the games classes also get unique abilities you can use.  There isn't a cover based system or anything, either your enemies can see and hit you or they can't. The graphics are dated, the item management is terrible,  there is a cutscene in an elevator to cover a loading screen, the combat is simplistic....  but the story, the characters and the game itself is compelling and a lot of fun. I already owned, and beat this game on the Xbox 360, but decided I wanted to import a save from Mass Effect 1 into Mass Effect 2 (and later 3) so I went back and repurchased the first game and played it all the way through prior to the release of ME2.  The game's story is that awesome!

content:
r 12, 2014
												The first thing that comes to mind when I think of Mass Effect is the thoroughness in how well thought out the universe is. The science - what's explained anyway - sounds interesting and plausible (not that I would really know). The concept of labeling any species as "goodguys" or "badguys" is hard to do since there are handfulls of both good and bad for each one (can't quite call any Hannar "bad" but no point nitpicking).The second thing I noticed was the story was really compelling in a way that felt more involving than other games. Think of Mass Effect as a videogame version of a "Choose Your Own Adventure" book. The choices you make can affect huge storylines that span the entire series. Sadly giving examples would spoil them. You can even unlock special actions/comments by raising meters gauging your Paragon and Renegade levels. That said almost every single active side quest was pretty repetitive. Go to planet. Drive on planet. Go in only building on planet. Kill a group of people. Collect loot.The combat is fun. How hard it is almost entirely depends on how well you are equipped. If you and your squad aren't equipped then you'll die sometimes. If they're well equipped most missions will typically be manageable on your first attempts. It might have been easier for me being I was an Engineer on my playthrough though - I destroyed shields and overheated weapons and hacked synthetic enemies to control the crowd a bit. I'm eager to try the game again as another class to see how different it would be.The driving parts with the Mako tank sometimes felt out of place. There were a few times it was major fun to drive. The missions involved obviously intended for the tank - like when driving it in the roofs of the ruins of skyscrapers - were awesome. However almost every planet you go to involves dropping onto the surface with the Mako tank before you drive around to check all the marked spots on a map (technically you could ignore them, but this is the most major way to run acrossed large money and some side-mission peices - which also possibly affect things later in the series). A lot of these worlds were mountainous and would make the Mako tank feel pretty mind numbingly slow on the incline.The inventory system was a mess. You could only hold so many items at a time and these items fill up fast on missions - between times you manage to run into a shop to unload them. This means you end up having to mess with it constantly. It's barely sorted in any way and it randomizes the entire list when you equip anything - making it a pain to find what you look for. It at least only shows items that fit in whatever slot you were trying to equip.The graphics were better than I expected them to be for a 10 year old game. Felt like what I usually have them set at for today's games.This game honestly feels like it should be added to some list of "Games Every Gamer Ought to Play." It feels like I'm playing a legend. Might have been because I've heard it's good for about 10 years.

												So I found Mass Effect on a Steam Sale back in 2013, and purchased it for hardly anything. I'd not read any reviews on the game, so had no idea what to expect once I bought it. I guess, truth be told, I only bought it because it was so cheap and I hoped it could fill a few hours one boring evening after work. Oh, sweet Mass Effect, you didn't disappoint! There aren't many games that I genuinely wish I could remove from my memory, in order to replay again with a fresh set of eyes, but the exceptional story of Mass Effect, combined with the excellent character acting, life and death decisions that you'll face, and Shepherd's development and rise from traumatised soldier to first human Spectre, is a real work of genius. Despite this game being made in 2008 (I think), I only started playing it in March 2014. In total, I've spent around 43 blissfully happy hours running through the main story and side quests (excluding those pesky 'collect so many of this type of tag' quests). I know many games don't age well, but Mass Effect doesn't look old, nor dated, and if I didn't know the age of this game, I'd quite truthfully believe it was new and current.I'll close by saying that anyone not already familiar with Mass Effect should buy it immediately - well, if you like story driven games, of course. If not, just wait for a Steam Sale and buy it when it's virtually free!Now, enough singing the praises of Mass Effect - I was also fortunate enough to buy Mass Effect 2 in the same sale. I just hope it lives up to my lofty expectations and doesn't lose the excitement built from this true classic!

content:
2, 2015
One of the best modern story-driven RPG's I've ever played. I have no complaints about ME1. I loved every minute of my 2 playthroughs. On my 5yr old PC there were no graphic glitches, no lag or issues of any kind. Just smooth sailing graphics & a wonderful story. The characters are well-written, even the ones you don't like (looking at you Ashley). As in KOTOR, you can go Light or Dark, good or bad, making Dialog choices to reflect your own personality or how you want Commander Shepard to be perceived. In this game at least, your choices don't really affect the endgame outcome. Your choices DO open up different dialog options and some side quests. It adds fun flavor to the game.I loved finding all the armor & weps scattered around everywhere you go. I liked the hacking puzzle mini-game to open caches. It reminded me of the similar hydraulic puzzle game in Bioshock, which I also loved - both the main game & the mini puzzle game.The DLC is FreeAnother plus for ME1 is the 2 DLC's are free & easily found to download. Some nice people have already linked them in other helpful reviews, or just Google.Common ComplaintsThe MakoSome people complain about the Mako, which if you haven't played the game yet, is a tank-like vehicle you drive when you explore planets. I personally loved driving the crazy thing. Yes, it can be hard to control. Things can get a little wild, but it's really not that hard & once you get the hang of it, driving it literally anywhere is good fun. Mostly though, combat in the thing with its cannon & gun are a literal blast.ExplorationSome people complained about exploring Planets. I personally enjoyed this aspect as well. You only explore at most, 1 planet per system, & exploring each planet only takes a few minutes. Of course, I did really like driving the Mako so any excuse to get in the thing & go nuts was welcome.Game Won't Start, or get a Black or White Screen then game won't startThis did actually happen to me once, but is VERY simple to fix. Find the game's .exe, right click it and select "Open as Administrator". If that doesn't work for you, exit Steam, then Right-click Steam to "Open As", THEN rt click ME1's .exe to "Open As". You should only ever have to do this once, then done. It happened to me at about 5hours in. I was frustrated for about 10 minutes before I found this simple solution. After that I just started the game normally for the rest of my playtime.Other Similar Games I recommend you play:Dragon Age SeriesMass Effect SeriesKOTOR SeriesBioshock Series - Especially 1, 2 & Minerva's Den DLC (Excellent standalone story there)All of those game titles are equal in my esteem. They all provide good value for the price & all have a great story. These games all really draw you in. IMO you just can't go wrong with any of them.Comments About ME2 & 3(*Included here because many people are buying 1&2 here together)While ME1 had only 2 DLC, both of which are now free, ME2 & ME3 both have numerous expensive DLC that never goes on sale. In fact, you can't just "buy" & DL DLC for those 2 games. Nope. Even though you can purchase ME2 on Steam, you have to go to Origin to get the DLC for it.Of course some people needlessly complain about Origin, but truthfully, Origin is awesome. It's a very solid Game Management / Store Interface, just as good as Steam for it's own purposes.Anyway, say you buy the ME1/2 pack here on Steam & you want to then buy DLC for the game, which must be done on Origin (or also on social.bioware.com). ME2/Deluxe does come with a tiny bit of DLC, which you can also activate on Origin along with the base game, should you wish to. Simple steps are needed: Install the game in Steam Right-click ME2 in your Steam library and "View CD Key" (The game must be installed to have this option) Open Origin. If you didn't already, create an account & log in. At the top left, click on Origin, then click "Redeem Product Code" There are 3 codes for ME2. Copy each from the little Steam window, one at a time, then paste to Activate in the Origin app. Find the game in your Origin Library, hover the mouse over it then click the little italicized "i", which opens a more detailed Information page.On the Info page you can see a list of all the DLC, much of which is free. However, the good stuff, namely the Content packs which give you more missions & not just fluff cosmetics, cost money.Actually, they cost "Bioware Points". Yes, it's lame, but there's no way around it. BC although Bioware makes insanely awesome games, the guy in charge of setting up the sale of DLC is obviously a crackhead. There's simply no other explanation for why they think this is a good idea, as opposed to just being able to put all the desired DLC in your cart then buying it all straight up.Nope. You put what you want in the cart, then when you Checkout......it takes you to buy Bioware Points. 1600 Points sells for $20, 1200/$15 & 800/$10. It's very simple math to figure out which DLC you really want then convert the dollar value to how many Bioware Points you need. It's really very annoying, but it's not that complicated.You're going to need ~$40 for all the ME2 DLC. More for ME3. So, even though you probably only paid $20 for all 3 games (on sale of course), you're going to probably be forking out $80+ more dollars for any content & cosmetics you may want for ME2 & ME3.One last note. I hear that DLC you buy for ME2 (in Origin of course) can also be activated in your Steam copy of the game, though I don't see the need to do it, so I've never tried. I honeslty don't know why you wouldn't just play it in Origin. But it's said to be possible should you wish to try it.Hope this info was helpful. Enjoy!

content:
, 2014
												Initial impression:10/10I've held this one aside for too long... "breathtaking, magnificent and absolutely magnetic in game-play"Time:39h odd for all the secondary content and some serious running in circles. (I found the 'minimum' minerals needed for one assignment, finding more doesn't matter and is never spoken of. otherwise 100%)bad points:Optimisation is very poor, I've turned a lot of the settings down to fix: After an hour or so the game GRINDS TO A HALT and the sounds get chewed up. I'm really not happy with this. (I can run the sequel without problems)This game feels like an "Elevator Simulator" ... (please tag product)-I mean SERIOUSLY want to know what it's like to stand in an elevator for 8 or 10 seconds EVERY 2 mins??? ... I've added a user interface command to selectively fast-forward its THAT BAD!The off-roader (MAKO) is pretty twitchy, and uncontrollable like it only wants to point N, NE, E... rather than steer in smooth circles plus it gets thrown about a lot with the exploration (off-world).Exploring other worlds with the Mako is a slow slow frustrating process, again thank goodness for the fast forward.Trying to walk on mountainous terrain: slow, the characters get stuck or simply can't climb anything that looks like a hill, failing that falling through the floor is a serious risk... This has happened rather a lot!There are a few long 'driving' sections which are a complete waste of time/game-play, I think the maps (both off-world and the driving sections) need an overhaul.I think the game moved a little too fast... Shepard seems to overnight gain the keys to the GALAXY... Makes me wonder exactly what did happen on Eden Prime????After 22h.... I'm sadden to say I feel almost ready for the story to wrap up. While the cites are just amazing the exploration off-world has too much obvious "recycling" ... It feels like fan-art or a mod!and it just doesn't bloody stop, pointless 'side-mission' after pointless 'side-mission'I few more story missions recouped my enthusiasm for the game, but not a replay yet... but I do have the sequel lined up.Overall I give this game 8.5/10 (recall my non-linear scoring system)

content:
ber 21, 2013
												If you haven't already purchased this game, you should go and purchase it right now.  Why? Well there's plenty of reasons. Mass Effect is the beginning to the phenomenal trilogy that revolutionized what it means to give a player choice.  In this game you are Shepard, a Commander in the Alliance Navy. Essentially you learn that the rogue Spectre, the galaxy's highest ranking police essentially, Saren is attempting to bring back the ancient machine race known as the Reapers. While tracking Saren down, Shepard meets many valuable teammates, and loses them, based on how you play.The dialogue in this game is centered mostly around a wheel with several parts, each having different types of dialogue choices. Want to attempt to save all the survivors of an attack? Sure. Want to punch the ♥♥♥♥♥y news-reporter in her face? Feel free, it's your choice. Choices, which do carry on the sequels, mind you. While the story and dialogue in the first game entice you to finish it, I do have to admit that the combat is not the best. It's pretty bad, but not too bad that it makes it unbearable to play. But don't worry, the problem is solved in the next game so don't lose hope. There are also a few bugs in the game that annoy you sometimes and also a few graphical errors, but nothing that will keep you from enjoying the masterpiece that is Mass Effect.On a scale of 1 to 10, I would gives Mass Effect a 9.2.

												I was told many years ago to play the Mass Effect series. I picked up the first on a Steam sale and it sat and sat, like these things tend to do. Earlier this year I moved to China and somehow magically that gave me more time to play games, so I started playing through my backlog. Well, Mass Effect was the first one I picked up, and I was not disapointed. I really dig the combination of RPG and third-person shooter. The story was decent, the cast of chracters strong, the voice acting suitable, graphics good enough for an old game. The side quests were a bit of a drag, reusing a lot of the same building layouts and enemy types, but I think that's pretty typical of sidequests, isn't it? I just bought ME2 on the Fall Sale, I'll get around to that right after I finish Dragon Age: Origins, Assassin's Creed, etc.

The combat is a bit bare-bones and almost seems to serve as a vehicle to progress the story at times, but it's worth it to meet new characters and explore exotic locales in your travels. 												OK! Seriously, you should get this phenomonal game, it's WELL worth the price tag of $20! content:
y 24, 2014
												It is hard to say just how much I love this game (and ME2) This game has everything you could want in an RPG, great story, great people that you come to care about in a small way. The only downside I can think of, is that in order to complete every possible thing you can, you do A LOT of "Moon Patrol" type play. Driving a vehicle on alien planets that are pretty much just bare and offer only small changes from the last naked alien planet you were driving on. You can however complete the game without doing EVERY part, and thus can avoid much of this.The best part of this game is how you can import your character into ME2 and the choices you made have an effect on what happens.My suggestion, if you can, is to start up ME2, and make your toon there first (face) get a code and THEN make it in ME1. Otherwise you import your toon and do not get a code, forcing you to start over making a face. Bad if you get attached to your Shepard, which happens easily.I suggest playing as a female Shepard, no, not (just) because of eye candy, but because I honestly feel that the female voice acting is better, and somehow the Shepard character makes more sense as a woman. Plus when you choose the renegade (badass) options, rather than the goodygoody options, it just makes them sound 100% cooler comming from a woman ^_^.

												This is one of those games that people seem to either love or just like.  I have never found anyone who hated it.  I am firmly in the "love" category.  One of those singleplayer experiences that you will remember forever.  Also, another one of the rare games that I find myself coming back to over and over again.  Like Deus Ex, it is basically a shooter with RPG elements (a TPS instead of an FPS).  Also like Deus Ex, you will find that there are often choices that you face in campaign that will change the gameplay and direction of the rest of the game.  Mass Effect has a perfect balance of choice, action, customizing, freedom, and intrigue to keep you coming back over and over again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Mass Effect is an amazing game.I first played it years ago when I was a young teenager,  when it was the only ME game out there and it shaped what I expected of gaming from then on. Everything from the atmosphere of the game (the music in particular is something to behold) to the narrative and how it plays out all feels well thought-out and engaging. Some of the plot and side-missions feel like they're plucked from generic sci-fi plotlines and remuddled a bit, but in ME's own way, it owns those factors and you no longer think "That whole alien queen speaking telepathically to someone has been done before" and rather think "Mass Effect did it and did it well." Your rampage across the galaxy to find this villain who's become a harbinger for the end of life as we know it is fun, and you care about it. Is it the same as every other game where you chase a world-ending villain and his/her catastrophes? Yep. Still fun.While, at this point, the graphics are a little outdated, you occasionally see something jaw dropping in Mass Effect. Smoke drifting diagonally away from lava-coated vistas (that you're DRIVING THROUGH) or a blinding, lilac sun on an alien horizon can, once-in-a-while, take your breath away.The dialogue is meticulously thought-out and well acted (while sometimes sounding a LITTLE dry) and it makes for a great dialogue-system where you know what you choose to say can and will have an effect on the outcome of a mission. It's one of the first games I played that implemented this. Although, while you have choices in ME, all those anastamosing plotlines end you up in the same place. That's not a downside (insert a philosophical quote about inevitability and fate here.) You still feel in control of your character and your future though and that's as much as you can ask for in a game.Gameplay-wise, it's fun, if a little simple. There aren't any puzzling moments (unless you count getting temporarily lost in one of the many hubs.) The game repeats a little when you have to play the same fight a few times to win. That's not a criticism. I'm all for old-school, 'git good' gaming.There are really only three or four main things you'll be doing in this game; shooting at and ducking from a wide variety of clever(ish) enemies, wandering around hub areas looking for answers to life's questions (and convincing people to do things), driving around in the MAKO (amazingly fun for something so simple) to explore planets, and zipping around the galaxy map to go do one of the three aforementioned activities.The combat is FUN and simple, but your two AI counterparts are fairly stupid and don't like to use cover like you do, so will get shot ALOT. Ordering them about feels like you're having to baby two other people whilst not dying in a firefight yourself, but you're Commander Shepherd. You can do it.Wandering back and forth in hub worlds like the Citadel is fun for about five minutes as it's all rather pretty, but eventually, talking to one character then running back to talk to another can get a bit boring and you wind up wanting to leap into some action again, which you can't without finishing your conversational wanderings. And prepare for ALOT of elevators. It's M.E.'s way of loading parts of maps while you're travelling but it takes you out of things a bit and they make you use elevators a whole lot. Boring, sadly.Planet exploring is fun and scenic (did I mention this game is beautiful?) especially in the MAKO. The vehicle is fun to drive around, even if it does have some crazy oversteer, but what do you expect when you're on the surface of some low-G moon driving over dunes and dustscapes? The guns feel powerful but don't bother trying to shoot anything near you as the thing can't aim down and the MAKO is quite tall. Just run over the enemies, dammit.They've put so much effort into fleshing out the characters and histories in this game; of you, your squad mates and beyond and it's all well voice acted. You can feel sparks fly not only between you and your teammates, but you notice which squadmates like each other and where rivalries lie in all the tiny ways. And everybody has their flaws. I love Ashley. No denying it there. I love her go-gettem attitude and her out of nowhere attraction to poetry. But she's also super racist against aliens, although she denies it. These aren't character tropes that come out of nowhere. Ashley's lived a life before you knew her and she's willing to tell you about it if you get to know her, from her gung-ho attitude she cultivated with her sister, to her father's love of poetry handed down to her, to her stoic patriotism towards Earth and Humanity leading to her distrust of alien races. Like her or not, she's human (irony intended); so much more than just a 3D rendered cardboard cutout. Now apply that detail to the dozens of characters, locations and races in Mass Effect. (All except Saren, the main villain of the game, who seems to just be a laughing, evil face with no deep backstory other than a foreboding 'he used to be what you are now.') They've sat down and thought this universe out. We NEED more people to do this when making games. It's probably the biggest selling point of Mass Effect. The galaxy has existed long before you arrived and will go on long after you leave (until ME3 maybe). You can ignore all of it; skip past the expositional dialogue or ignore informative text boxes altogether. But if you want the lore, it's all there and it's beautiful. Plus, they make a GOOD attempt at sciencing everything well. It's what makes for 'science-fiction' rather than 'space-fantasy.'So, to sum up:+This game is STILL beautiful after all these years.+The people and locations are so detailed in lore and history that you can't help but love them all. +You feel in control of yourself in a vast universe where everything seems to be going wrong.+The gameplay is fun and simple, and there's a lot of it.+ Hit the jets on the MAKO while driving up a mountain and try to do a backflip!!!- The gameplay can get a little repetitive.- Slightly generic (but forgivable) plotlines, particularly in some side missions.- Ultimately, you're choices don't change the ultimate outcome of the game, but it shows how small you are in this huge story anyway, and serves to drive home that point. (So, secretly a positive?)The negatives are small and are hugely outweighed by the positives.9/10.*Cue opening thematic music***Doooooo dooo doooooooooo doooooo**

0, 2015
												Admittedly, when I started playing this game, I didn't have high hopes for it. In a wide galaxy, you play as a human named Shepard, who saves the galaxy and either makes everyone feel bad about how awful they are, or punches everyone in the face. Either way, it's a win/win situation.It's region based open world, which means a lot of the time you will be running around the map trying to find a fast travel spot, but that's the fun part. You get to see a LOT of planets, drive a Mako (probably flip it and be unable to get up a mountain with it), and have aliens join your entourage. As the first game in the franchise, the graphics leave a little to be desired, but it makes up for that with it's combat, storyline, and heartbreaking decisions.All in all, Mass Effect is one of my favorite games, and it's always nice to return to the foundation of the series and make a new Shepard, new choices, and find a new love interest.10/10

content:
, 2015
												The Mass Effect series is not for everyone. But for those of us who enjoy immersive stories that develop relationships and fuel rivalries it may well be to your liking. The first installment is a bit dated now but very (re)playable if the content is enjoyed. Though many decisions may not have incredible impacts on the overall story, their importance will have much to do with how your team perceives you. Your role is to bring together a team of companions on a hunt for a rogue leader of an army seeking to welcome the coming of a powerful force. This series is up there for me with the Elder Scrolls. It's a sci-fi analog for magical fantasy. I've played every one of the three games at least three times through, and I expect I will be starting a fourth before long. For those with RPG inclinations that enjoy the action of a shooter, strategy of a tactical game, the building of relationships and character development, and the roaming of celestial bodies for treasures and trouble I would highly recommend giving this a try.There are some scenes in this game that have stuck with me since!As an aside, should the games side quests be too burdensome but the main story keeps your interest I would recommend focusing on the main quest for its pleasure and enjoy the sequel's polished gameplay!

												Mass Effect is not a sandbox/open-world RPG.  This game is not about shooting things because you can.  This game, is above that.  This game plays a psychological role in your life, depending on whether you allow it to or not.  If it is to be held as an open-world RPG, let the world be the minds of each person you meet, whether for the first time or the last.  Personally, I believe this is more of an RPG than TES or Fallout, as the role you play shows an impact on the world around you, and the decisions you make can decide whether or not you live as a role-model of humanity or a menace that holds importance.

content:
4, 2016
												Great game. Great universe. Above all, I applaud the dialogue wheel options. Questions I was asking myself were listed which made conversations feel natural, and and the game didn't use Charm or Intimidate skill to resolve most of its story. I'm usually set on what choices my character would make in an RPG, but I actually took a step back a few times to think of the consequences of my actions. Really makes me want to play the game a few more times to see how other choices will affect the game.I'm not a huge fan of dynamic leveling in games especially RPGs where progression matters, but I wish they had added it to this game. When they offer you a universe to quest through it's very easy to make mistakes. One of your first quest options when you get your ship is to find Liara between several planets in a system. The first planet I searched ended up being for level 30's while I was only level 8. I kept dying and I thought I was playing the game wrong because I was new and it took almost two hours to finish it before I found out it was a separate optional quest. Romances felt forced. It seemed as if BioWare tried to use romance as a selling point of the game or something. Although it's kinda acceptable with the way your character interacts with everyone but it was still too blunt. I talked to Ashley once about her history and suddenly she's fighting with Liara over who I love more. It only happened because Ashley herself told me to talk to Liara after her mother dies and Liara suddenly falls in love with me. It seemed unnecessary.Other than those small grievances, the game was great and I'm looking forward to playing the 2nd and 3rd games. Amazed it took me this long to play it.

content:
7, 2015
												Mass Effect is a role-playing shooter in a beautifully realized sci-fi world. It was the second-to-last game made by the – legendary – game studio Bioware, before the inevitable quality decline set in, that occurs when a studio is incorporated into the EA roster.Even though Mass Effect was originally an Xbox 360 exclusive, Bioware did not let the limited hardware hinder the game's potential. The game was a visual masterpiece, and the tight movement and combat naturally inherited from the Unreal Engine played wonderfully into the game's core shooting mechanics. The intense firefights with lasers, explosions, and kinetic powers, kept you at the edge of your seat – but it was the expansive universe, and heavy story elements, that kept you from leaving it.If I were to make a parallel between another much beloved piece of media, I'd say that Mass Effect followed the Matrix formula to a T. Much akin to the Matrix trilogy, the first part of the Mass Effect trilogy is an independent piece that stands on its own, it builds up a mysterious and interesting world, and let's you take it in however much you like – but just like the Matrix trilogy, the second and third parts thoroughly disappoint.Why The Matrix trilogy went the way it did is a mystery only the Wachowskis can answer for, but as for Mass Effect, we can clearly point our fingers at EA and say: “They did it!”. Mass Effect, along with Dragon Age: Origins, were Bioware's final games that showed the brilliance of the studio. The games that followed are little more than fan-service on top of bad writing. Let's not even start with The Old Republic.As for Mass Effect, it's one of the most fleshed out worlds ever created. The game hooks you from the start, and won't let go – even when the credits roll. You're gonna wanna go back, and it's recommended, as the game has twists and turns that will only reveal themselves on second or third playthroughs. I recommend this game to anyone and everyone.

												Admittedly, when I started playing this game, I didn't have high hopes for it. In a wide galaxy, you play as a human named Shepard, who saves the galaxy and either makes everyone feel bad about how awful they are, or punches everyone in the face. Either way, it's a win/win situation.It's region based open world, which means a lot of the time you will be running around the map trying to find a fast travel spot, but that's the fun part. You get to see a LOT of planets, drive a Mako (probably flip it and be unable to get up a mountain with it), and have aliens join your entourage. As the first game in the franchise, the graphics leave a little to be desired, but it makes up for that with it's combat, storyline, and heartbreaking decisions.All in all, Mass Effect is one of my favorite games, and it's always nice to return to the foundation of the series and make a new Shepard, new choices, and find a new love interest.10/10

												When I first heard about Mass Effect, I was quite skeptical on how good it could really be. It is with great honor that I deem my previous thoughts unworthy. Mass Effect is the first of a trilogy, and it holds the rank as being one of the greats. However, tedious inventory management, dated graphics, and planet exploration on a space car that handles badly, are some of the downsides, but put those aside, and there is a great story with great characters awaiting. The story begins with Commander Shepard going on a mission to be tested to be a Spectre, but things go awry, as repected Spectre Saren goes rogue, and things don't go according to plan. Now Shepard must save the galaxy from Saren and his synthetic partners from an ancient evil altogether. Characters are varied, with humans mixed along with some aliens in Commander Shepard's squad. Weapons and armor are numerous, with also mods to put on the armor and weapons. All in all, a great sci-fi RPG that has to be played.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 12, 2014
												The first thing that comes to mind when I think of Mass Effect is the thoroughness in how well thought out the universe is. The science - what's explained anyway - sounds interesting and plausible (not that I would really know). The concept of labeling any species as "goodguys" or "badguys" is hard to do since there are handfulls of both good and bad for each one (can't quite call any Hannar "bad" but no point nitpicking).The second thing I noticed was the story was really compelling in a way that felt more involving than other games. Think of Mass Effect as a videogame version of a "Choose Your Own Adventure" book. The choices you make can affect huge storylines that span the entire series. Sadly giving examples would spoil them. You can even unlock special actions/comments by raising meters gauging your Paragon and Renegade levels. That said almost every single active side quest was pretty repetitive. Go to planet. Drive on planet. Go in only building on planet. Kill a group of people. Collect loot.The combat is fun. How hard it is almost entirely depends on how well you are equipped. If you and your squad aren't equipped then you'll die sometimes. If they're well equipped most missions will typically be manageable on your first attempts. It might have been easier for me being I was an Engineer on my playthrough though - I destroyed shields and overheated weapons and hacked synthetic enemies to control the crowd a bit. I'm eager to try the game again as another class to see how different it would be.The driving parts with the Mako tank sometimes felt out of place. There were a few times it was major fun to drive. The missions involved obviously intended for the tank - like when driving it in the roofs of the ruins of skyscrapers - were awesome. However almost every planet you go to involves dropping onto the surface with the Mako tank before you drive around to check all the marked spots on a map (technically you could ignore them, but this is the most major way to run acrossed large money and some side-mission peices - which also possibly affect things later in the series). A lot of these worlds were mountainous and would make the Mako tank feel pretty mind numbingly slow on the incline.The inventory system was a mess. You could only hold so many items at a time and these items fill up fast on missions - between times you manage to run into a shop to unload them. This means you end up having to mess with it constantly. It's barely sorted in any way and it randomizes the entire list when you equip anything - making it a pain to find what you look for. It at least only shows items that fit in whatever slot you were trying to equip.The graphics were better than I expected them to be for a 10 year old game. Felt like what I usually have them set at for today's games.This game honestly feels like it should be added to some list of "Games Every Gamer Ought to Play." It feels like I'm playing a legend. Might have been because I've heard it's good for about 10 years.

content:

												The first two times I played this game, it was on the lowly XBox 360.  The game was already very dated five years ago, or so it seemed.  My third playthrough, and my first on the PC, and I'm seeing stunning visuals and textures that were simply not present on the console version.  The game looks worlds better than I remember.  Controls are better (except for the vehicle), and it helps to have a deep understanding of game mechanics from playing all three multiple times through.  My first playthrough of this game was frustratingly difficult because I didn't understand what type of character I had picked or how to properly use the powers.  I suggest a revisit to this game for anyone who liked this series.  Tip:  If anyone's having trouble running this game, or using Steam overlay while playing, close Steam, and reopen it as Administrator.  The games will inherit the permissions, and everything will work fine. Tip 2:  For anyone having trouble with resolution settings, dig into the Steam game folder for Mass Effect.  There's a launcher in there that lets you change settings, including increasing resolution (for me, 2560 x 1600, but anything 16:10 will need to be set via this launcher to look correct, because the game will only show 16:9 resolutions while looking at in-game settings.)

												So I found Mass Effect on a Steam Sale back in 2013, and purchased it for hardly anything. I'd not read any reviews on the game, so had no idea what to expect once I bought it. I guess, truth be told, I only bought it because it was so cheap and I hoped it could fill a few hours one boring evening after work. Oh, sweet Mass Effect, you didn't disappoint! There aren't many games that I genuinely wish I could remove from my memory, in order to replay again with a fresh set of eyes, but the exceptional story of Mass Effect, combined with the excellent character acting, life and death decisions that you'll face, and Shepherd's development and rise from traumatised soldier to first human Spectre, is a real work of genius. Despite this game being made in 2008 (I think), I only started playing it in March 2014. In total, I've spent around 43 blissfully happy hours running through the main story and side quests (excluding those pesky 'collect so many of this type of tag' quests). I know many games don't age well, but Mass Effect doesn't look old, nor dated, and if I didn't know the age of this game, I'd quite truthfully believe it was new and current.I'll close by saying that anyone not already familiar with Mass Effect should buy it immediately - well, if you like story driven games, of course. If not, just wait for a Steam Sale and buy it when it's virtually free!Now, enough singing the praises of Mass Effect - I was also fortunate enough to buy Mass Effect 2 in the same sale. I just hope it lives up to my lofty expectations and doesn't lose the excitement built from this true classic!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 4
												So after all these years of hearing the hype I couldn't curb my curiosity any longer and finally bought Mass Effect and its sequel during the last christmas sales. As of now I've played about three quarters of Mass Effect and though I initially liked it I have to say I'm getting bored with it. Though that may sound negative I still give it a 3 out of 5 because it's a competent game but in my oppinion it doesn't deserve the praise it's getting.If you're familiar with Biowares previous products like Jade Empire and especially Knights Of The Old Republic (KOTOR)  you pretty much know what to expect from Mass Effect. Personally I think Mass Effect was probably meant to be another KOTOR installment, because its entire world could have been replaced with the one from KOTOR without much change, the Jedi order is now Spectre, the Jedi counsil is now The Counsil, the Force powers are now Biotic powers, the Twileks are now Asari, the Mandalorians are now Krogans and the list goes on. Maybe they couldn't secure the Star Wars license, not that it matters (unless you still care about Star Wars) because Bioware did a desent job in creating this new backdrop.Still I think this game shows why Bioware is becoming lazy as it's yet another save the universe story, which is way to similar to KOTOR. Like in Biowares earlier mentioned games, new partymembers join with no effort and are immediately willing to die for the cause. This is not only a missed opportunity for having better sidequests, it also makes their motives in joining meaningless. Mass Effect has some of the worst sidequests I've witnessed, the game has you looking for minerals with your APC by searching entire maps, to laughable moral decissions like wether a (completely bystanding) pregnant woman should have her baby inspected, which really made me question myself what I'm doing with my life by playing Mass Effect. For god's sake, Bioware please don't try to forcefeed me with morally responsible gameplay because you are terrible at it!As for the combat, the enemies are ridiculous bulletsponges which makes your weapons feel completely ineffective, I know this is in a lot of games but when I shoot something I expect it to hurt! As for me I was a bulletsponge too, so I didn't bother to make use of the coversystem much and I played on hard level. The shotgun and the assault rifle were the only usable weapons. I didn't see why I needed the pistol as drawing to a different weapon took as long as your gun to cool down and using the sniperrifle was like a drunk man playing darts. Another extremely annoying thing is that you have to have a high techlevel to be able to open all the containers, which in the end made me play only with Tali and Garrus as teammembers. I also thought that Mass Effect had rather poor graphics even for 2008, the characters have latexfaces, the leveldesign is rather bland and textures are very lowres, on the other hand I did like the music.So if you haven't played KOTOR or Jade Empire you might like Mass Effect more than me, if you have already played those you'll probably gonna need something to keep you awake while playing this game.

content:
, 2015
												I've finally got around to beginning the Mass Effect series, and numero uno was a blast. An incredibly immersive, well crafted and believable universe, I found myself happily getting lost in the cultural depth and history created here, of the Geth, Krogan, Turian, Rachni and more. Mass Effect features a wide range of well written, memorable characters (Liara, Wrex, Garrus, Saren, Anderson, Sovereign, could go on), some great clever dialogue and many funny moments, as well as more painful ones as the consequences of your actions play out through the story. One of the best aspects of the game as you progress is simply getting to know your crewmates that you're choosing to work with mission by mission. The music is fantastic, and acts beautifully to create atmosphere and in binding all the various parts of the game together (Vigil, Galaxy Map theme i'm looking at you). For a title released in 2007/2008 the graphics seem to have endured really well, and again fit perfectly with the overall feel of the game. While you're exploring planets be sure to stop and take a few seconds at the summit of a mountain and look out at the vista before you, it's pretty damn gorgeous. Gameplay wise, combat is fun and pretty well balanced, if a little on the easy side. I found biotic abilities particularly enjoyable, there's also a lot of room to customise gear and weapons as you see fit, especially later in the game. Movement is kept varied in space or on land, between exploring new worlds/buildings on foot or by roaming and driving up sheer cliffs in the Mako, hopping around the interior of the Normandy and navigating the Galaxy Map, there is a real and epic sense of scale here (Moon landing included), and the freedom to seek it out.The only slight cons I can think of are somewhat repetitive sidequests; with a bouncy tin tank that has some infamous clunky manoeuvring, and slowpoke elevators (which excellent dialogue and hilarious music almost make up for). The inventory can become a bit tricky to manage. Worlds explored outside of main quests could also be more detailed and fleshed out in terms of content beyond markers on the map. Summary: A brilliant and deeply satisfying narrative experience overall, and I will be coming back for more playthroughs after visiting the next installments of Mass Effect. Just play it.

content:
6, 2014
												Mass Effect is not a sandbox/open-world RPG.  This game is not about shooting things because you can.  This game, is above that.  This game plays a psychological role in your life, depending on whether you allow it to or not.  If it is to be held as an open-world RPG, let the world be the minds of each person you meet, whether for the first time or the last.  Personally, I believe this is more of an RPG than TES or Fallout, as the role you play shows an impact on the world around you, and the decisions you make can decide whether or not you live as a role-model of humanity or a menace that holds importance.

												Admittedly, when I started playing this game, I didn't have high hopes for it. In a wide galaxy, you play as a human named Shepard, who saves the galaxy and either makes everyone feel bad about how awful they are, or punches everyone in the face. Either way, it's a win/win situation.It's region based open world, which means a lot of the time you will be running around the map trying to find a fast travel spot, but that's the fun part. You get to see a LOT of planets, drive a Mako (probably flip it and be unable to get up a mountain with it), and have aliens join your entourage. As the first game in the franchise, the graphics leave a little to be desired, but it makes up for that with it's combat, storyline, and heartbreaking decisions.All in all, Mass Effect is one of my favorite games, and it's always nice to return to the foundation of the series and make a new Shepard, new choices, and find a new love interest.10/10

content:
4, 2016
												Great game. Great universe. Above all, I applaud the dialogue wheel options. Questions I was asking myself were listed which made conversations feel natural, and and the game didn't use Charm or Intimidate skill to resolve most of its story. I'm usually set on what choices my character would make in an RPG, but I actually took a step back a few times to think of the consequences of my actions. Really makes me want to play the game a few more times to see how other choices will affect the game.I'm not a huge fan of dynamic leveling in games especially RPGs where progression matters, but I wish they had added it to this game. When they offer you a universe to quest through it's very easy to make mistakes. One of your first quest options when you get your ship is to find Liara between several planets in a system. The first planet I searched ended up being for level 30's while I was only level 8. I kept dying and I thought I was playing the game wrong because I was new and it took almost two hours to finish it before I found out it was a separate optional quest. Romances felt forced. It seemed as if BioWare tried to use romance as a selling point of the game or something. Although it's kinda acceptable with the way your character interacts with everyone but it was still too blunt. I talked to Ashley once about her history and suddenly she's fighting with Liara over who I love more. It only happened because Ashley herself told me to talk to Liara after her mother dies and Liara suddenly falls in love with me. It seemed unnecessary.Other than those small grievances, the game was great and I'm looking forward to playing the 2nd and 3rd games. Amazed it took me this long to play it.

content:
2015
												Mass Effect is a story-rich FPS where you play as Shepard, in a time where the universe is starting to realise the potential of the human species in taking up bigger responsibilities alongside others. Initially under Captain Anderson's command, you are tasked to investigate a distress signal on a planet and during which, you discover that a trusted ally is setting something shady into motion. Throughout the game. you hunt him down and discover the secrets that would have implications on everyone in the known universe.The game focuses strongly on the story, during which you would have to make a number of decisions that although may not change the story itself, they translate to your character stats, and also the (remaining) crew that you fight with. (And also your sex life lmao.) The combat system is pretty good in that you fight in a section of 3, where your crew could provide interesting powers or just be meat shields as you recharge your own powerups. However, some hostiles such as snipers or rocket turrets could possibly one-shot Shepard and you would have to restart from where the game last saved. Hence, I do recommend that you consistently manual save or you might have to replay a large part of the mission.I find the game very well-rounded and enjoyable, back by an interesting story. However, one major set back to the action for me would be the extremely long elevator rides. Seems silly but you would have to play it to understand the agony :)9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2, 2012
												590 hours.  Thats 24 unblinking, unsleeping days with the crew of the Normandy.According to the combined statistics of Steam, and Origin. Over a hundred fourty hours went into the original Mass Effect (four playthroughs), 289 hours into Mass Effect 2 (six playthroughs), and 219 hours into Mass Effect 3 (two compleate playthroughs, many incompleate) and 8 hours into ME4 Andromeda.Commander Shepard and her crew(no one should play as male Shep imho), have done plenty of galaxy saving, and stirring up,  under my control. They fought, robots, clones, politicians, and reporters. They made love to aliens, hate to aliens, and even saved a race from going compleatly extinct!  We laughed, cried, got wasted, and most importantly fought beside one another through thick and thin.They're my friends.OK, they're not really my friends; claiming to be buddies with imaginary characters is a little too geeky even for me. The Mass Effect series is not without its flaws, and some are truly Reaper-sized. But it has gripped me like nothing else in the history of video games, and video games and I go back a pretty long way (but I'll never betoo old for video games)!The Mass Effect universe is that rare thing—a fully-realized science fiction game setting that stands up to the likes of Star Trek or Star Wars. The universe in which the games take place has a rich and complex backstory, and even better, it's not a rich and complex back story that the player has to have info-dumped into his head. This isn't The Old Republic, where you have to read thousands of awful Kevin J. Anderson "Extended Universe" novels and have a working knowledge of the seven prime forms of lightsaber combat to get the most out of the game.There's depth in the backstory, but it's not the kind of depth that ever compelled me to memorize the game's codex entries. (Do you really need to know that the "First Contact War" between humans and Turians started because humans activated a mass relay in violation of council law and that the war culminated in the siege of Shanxi? No. It's wonderful flavor, but it's not mandatory knowledge.) The world is alive and compellingly real just through dialogue and character actions, without needing endless narration. The first game's opening title crawl essentially says, "This is the future and aliens are real and you are a space soldier. Go." That's enough.Instead of a galactic civics lesson, Mass Effect focuses on a human, the forever-first-nameless Commander Shepard, and her fight against the ancient Reapers, an enemy that aims to rid the galaxy of advanced sentient life for a whole bunch of really complicated reasons. That fight is the central focus of all three games, though Shepard's path from soldier to savior twists and turns and doubles back on itself like a demented snake.

content:
r 27, 2013
												Mass Effect stands the test of time.  As you approach the climax of this story, it is like any good book, you simply cannot put it down.  You want to get to the end, whether you have read it before or not, you must finish.  This is a great thing for Mass Effect, its story helps keep it relevant as things like game graphics in more modern games become far superior. With little knowledge about the second game beyond knowing one exists the story of Mass Effect holds up and it resembles that book you can't put down  The gameplay remains as great as the story which intertwined with a more fast paced RPG (when compared to other BioWare RPG releases of similar period). Upon a current play through, the graphics appear aged but that is expected.  If you consider yourself at least moderately okay at understanding how to install items I highly recommend installing the Mass Effect 1 New Texture Updates mod. This updates a gargantuan amount of textures within Mass Effect.  Its not that the graphics weren't good at release, its that with time that is one thing that almost always changes for the better.  This mod allows a facelift, bringing many of the textures in line with the other great material in the game that has stood the test of time.Whether you have played it once (or more) already or you have yet to experience Mass Effect, this game is worthy tof residing on anyone's playlist.

content:
4, 2013
												After bunches of strangers posted to me about Mass Effect, I finally gave it a go. Space-themed game with focus on story? Sounds right up my alley.Right away, I need to criticize the main city of the game, the Citadel. Who in the world designed this mess? I'm not saying it's fugly. In fact, it looks quite nice. It's just that it's poorly laid out and needlessly labyrinthine... especially for a main hub of the game.The shooter aspect was okay. I'm not really a first or third person shooter type, but it worked, and it was playable, so I'll leave it at that.I'm still not exactly sure what the point of scanning planets for resources was. It was hardly crucial to the plot or gameplay. Just a pure homage to Star Control?Replay value is... there. I admit I would have liked to go back and earn some achievements that provide rewards, but the gameplay just wasn't enticing enough to me to warrant a second playthrough. I need to note that playing as a Paragon is boring as hell. I recommend trying out a Renegade to bring out the more interesting conversations.The game has excellent atmosphere, and some pretty interesting alien backstory. I don't quite understand the trend of cramming in bucketloads of irrelevant information in the in-game encyclopedia, but I guess there's an audience for it. The strength of the game I feel is in the character conversations, but those weren't as frequent as I would have liked.Overall I'd have to say I wasn't disappointed. I wasn't blown away by the plot, though that's my fault for setting a high expectation. The main story isn't the kind of story that makes you a better person for having experienced it, but it was interesting nonetheless, especially towards the end. Still not Planescape: Torment caliber. 8.5/10

content:
22, 2014
												Everyone told me that I wouldn't love all of BioWare's games, but there would be one series that resonates with me indefinitely, and that was Mass Effect.ME brought to me a host of things I have never seen in a game before: an active, beautiful storyline full of wonderful lore (via the codex) that not only made me very intimate with what was going on, but also impacted how I played the game. A story where your decisions actually impact how the story progresses.The graphics certainly weren't anything to shake a stick at. They were solid for the time period, but definitely not anything mind blowing. The music was wonderful, with plenty of jams that I enjoyed along the way.The gameplay is what truly stood out to me. I'm not a big fan of shooters, but this game allowed me to appreciate them. Tie in some RPG elements to anything and I'll be willing to give it a go. The vast planets that you can explore and the isolation of some of them really made you feel like you were a part of a universe that was very real.I don't have enough good words to say about ME. If you've never played it at all, I urge you to pick it up and give it a go, no matter what kind of a gamer you classify yourself as.
