content:
2015
												Mass Effect is a story-rich FPS where you play as Shepard, in a time where the universe is starting to realise the potential of the human species in taking up bigger responsibilities alongside others. Initially under Captain Anderson's command, you are tasked to investigate a distress signal on a planet and during which, you discover that a trusted ally is setting something shady into motion. Throughout the game. you hunt him down and discover the secrets that would have implications on everyone in the known universe.The game focuses strongly on the story, during which you would have to make a number of decisions that although may not change the story itself, they translate to your character stats, and also the (remaining) crew that you fight with. (And also your sex life lmao.) The combat system is pretty good in that you fight in a section of 3, where your crew could provide interesting powers or just be meat shields as you recharge your own powerups. However, some hostiles such as snipers or rocket turrets could possibly one-shot Shepard and you would have to restart from where the game last saved. Hence, I do recommend that you consistently manual save or you might have to replay a large part of the mission.I find the game very well-rounded and enjoyable, back by an interesting story. However, one major set back to the action for me would be the extremely long elevator rides. Seems silly but you would have to play it to understand the agony :)9.5/10

content:
er 28, 2014
												PROS:+ Definitely one of the most interesting, yet complex plots out there+ Gameplay is dynamically shaped by your actions and dialogue selections+ Can go around as a total ♥♥♥♥, or an ethical and universal role model+ Epic protagonist+ Fluid game mechanics+ Does a decent job getting your emotions a little worked up+ Viable for replayability+ Most maps are impressively immersive+ AI is actually pretty good+ Different alien species can be fun to learn more about+ Gives the player the option to play strategically with the eccentric specialties of each squad member+ Fun side quests, with some being humorous+ Even after understanding the plot 100%, there are still unresolvable mysteries that leave the players to assume for themselves+ Awesome voice acting, but Shepard's can start to sound monotone after a while+ Textures are a little meh, but are enough to keep you immersed+ Lotsa lens flares+ Optional and unintrusive romanceCONS:- Citadel is large and can be too confusing to navigate through- Too many useless elevators- Walking/jogging speed is kind of slow- Inventory system is really annoying to use- Sound sometimes, but rarely, started acting whacky for me- Exploring ("landing on") planets that are extraneous to the main plot can sometimes be rewarding, but are mostly "cookie cutter'ed"- Music is very sci-fi'y, but sometimes annoyed me due to the short loops- Gun model variation is pretty unexciting (maybe 2 models per type, with about 3 colors per model)- No free-roam after completing game, so make sure you do all the side-quests you're interested in and explore BEORE you begin the final quest

content:
y 8, 2015
												When I first heard about Mass Effect, I was quite skeptical on how good it could really be. It is with great honor that I deem my previous thoughts unworthy. Mass Effect is the first of a trilogy, and it holds the rank as being one of the greats. However, tedious inventory management, dated graphics, and planet exploration on a space car that handles badly, are some of the downsides, but put those aside, and there is a great story with great characters awaiting. The story begins with Commander Shepard going on a mission to be tested to be a Spectre, but things go awry, as repected Spectre Saren goes rogue, and things don't go according to plan. Now Shepard must save the galaxy from Saren and his synthetic partners from an ancient evil altogether. Characters are varied, with humans mixed along with some aliens in Commander Shepard's squad. Weapons and armor are numerous, with also mods to put on the armor and weapons. All in all, a great sci-fi RPG that has to be played.

content:
14, 2014
												Finally acceding to the recommendations of countless friends I decided to try out Mass Effect. What I found was one of the best games I have played in a long time (perhaps among the best I have ever played). It is a great RPG set in a beautifully crafted universe. Although it can certainly be accused of being quite linear, Mass Effect boasts a gripping story full of truly meaningful choices with lasting consequences. Your words and actions have real meaning and in a universe full of such likeable characters it really provides the player with a depth of immersion rarely attained in a video game and BioWare deserves full credit for attaining this feat of artistic skill.I truly recommend checking out this title if you are a fan of RPGs or interactive choice-based games (i.e. Telltale). One of the best out there. 9.5/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
												Mass Effect has a rich and engaging story line with some of the best writing I've seen in a video game. It really feels like you are actively participating in a movie and the actions you take (or don't take) leave an a "flavorful" impact on the game's story. The game is worth the purchase of just experiencing the rich story.However, from a gameplay perspective there are some issues. First off all but 1 or 2 squadmates are completely useless, they don't seem to understand how shot blockers work and will just fire in a linear path to the target of choice. The game also relies heavily on quick saves and I suggest you use them because there are a lot of enemies and wepaons that will just flat-out 1 shot you with no warning. The areas you explore and visit, particularly for side quests become very repativie and re-used. You generally are performing the same type of mission but with different enemies or a different story behind why you are shooting things in the face, and a lot of the level designs are copy pasted from previous sides quests.Additionally the "hacking" you do is fun for roughly the first 8 seconds, afterwards just spend omni-gel to unlock stuff.  If I were to compare this first game of a AAA series to another I would compare it to how I felt playing Assasins Creed. Both ME1 and AC1 suffer from similar issues, re-used level design, repetative mission (particularly side quests) and clunky controls. That being said both were fun to play and offered about 20-30 hours of solid, fun gameplay. If you have not played the Mass Effect series ME1 will not dissapoint you. Definitely an easy pickup during a sale and well worth your money.8/10+Strong Story+Great voice acting and characters-Repetative side-quests-Poor squad AI-Clunky Controls

content:
er 26, 2015
												I just got this for a couple of bucks, and after not playing it for several years, I got to say that this game has aged quite well in my opinion. For today's standards (regarding graphics and whatnot), it still holds up, and has some pretty good visuals. They do look a bit dated, of course, but for a game originally released in 2007, it looks great. Several people have complained about the Mako (driving) sections, and while the controls are a bit wonky, it still is a good idea, and it's not as bad as most people make it sound. And now,  let's talk about the heart of this game, and what makes it so special; the expanding, interesting, epic and completely immersive story filled with fully fleshed characters that you care about, amazing plot-twists, and an open ended narrative. This is what makes the ME series so special, along with it's bigger-than life space opera setting. Finally, I have to say that this game is a bargain. It offers at least 30 hours of gameplay, and if you explore every little corner and do every single side quests, those 30 hours could easily stretch to 50. Get this thing ASAP.

												This is one of those games that people seem to either love or just like.  I have never found anyone who hated it.  I am firmly in the "love" category.  One of those singleplayer experiences that you will remember forever.  Also, another one of the rare games that I find myself coming back to over and over again.  Like Deus Ex, it is basically a shooter with RPG elements (a TPS instead of an FPS).  Also like Deus Ex, you will find that there are often choices that you face in campaign that will change the gameplay and direction of the rest of the game.  Mass Effect has a perfect balance of choice, action, customizing, freedom, and intrigue to keep you coming back over and over again.

												Great futuristic RPG based on our universe in somewhat fantasy setting. You play as commander Shepard who is pretty much a one man, a one ship crew army. Wont spoil much, this game has great story, a lot of characters and character interaction via cut scene dialogues. Great galaxy to explore with a lot of planets to land on, stations to visit and side quests to do. Has a lot of choice and consequence so think carefully what you say, as the response will shape your character to be good or evil. Game has great visuals, voice acting and animations. Make sure you keep your saves if you plan on playing ME 2, ME 3, etc., as you can transfer them and keep your progress and story over to the next game. I enjoyed this a lot, one of the best if not the best sci-fi RPG of my time.

												Initial impression:10/10I've held this one aside for too long... "breathtaking, magnificent and absolutely magnetic in game-play"Time:39h odd for all the secondary content and some serious running in circles. (I found the 'minimum' minerals needed for one assignment, finding more doesn't matter and is never spoken of. otherwise 100%)bad points:Optimisation is very poor, I've turned a lot of the settings down to fix: After an hour or so the game GRINDS TO A HALT and the sounds get chewed up. I'm really not happy with this. (I can run the sequel without problems)This game feels like an "Elevator Simulator" ... (please tag product)-I mean SERIOUSLY want to know what it's like to stand in an elevator for 8 or 10 seconds EVERY 2 mins??? ... I've added a user interface command to selectively fast-forward its THAT BAD!The off-roader (MAKO) is pretty twitchy, and uncontrollable like it only wants to point N, NE, E... rather than steer in smooth circles plus it gets thrown about a lot with the exploration (off-world).Exploring other worlds with the Mako is a slow slow frustrating process, again thank goodness for the fast forward.Trying to walk on mountainous terrain: slow, the characters get stuck or simply can't climb anything that looks like a hill, failing that falling through the floor is a serious risk... This has happened rather a lot!There are a few long 'driving' sections which are a complete waste of time/game-play, I think the maps (both off-world and the driving sections) need an overhaul.I think the game moved a little too fast... Shepard seems to overnight gain the keys to the GALAXY... Makes me wonder exactly what did happen on Eden Prime????After 22h.... I'm sadden to say I feel almost ready for the story to wrap up. While the cites are just amazing the exploration off-world has too much obvious "recycling" ... It feels like fan-art or a mod!and it just doesn't bloody stop, pointless 'side-mission' after pointless 'side-mission'I few more story missions recouped my enthusiasm for the game, but not a replay yet... but I do have the sequel lined up.Overall I give this game 8.5/10 (recall my non-linear scoring system)

content:
er 26, 2015
												I just got this for a couple of bucks, and after not playing it for several years, I got to say that this game has aged quite well in my opinion. For today's standards (regarding graphics and whatnot), it still holds up, and has some pretty good visuals. They do look a bit dated, of course, but for a game originally released in 2007, it looks great. Several people have complained about the Mako (driving) sections, and while the controls are a bit wonky, it still is a good idea, and it's not as bad as most people make it sound. And now,  let's talk about the heart of this game, and what makes it so special; the expanding, interesting, epic and completely immersive story filled with fully fleshed characters that you care about, amazing plot-twists, and an open ended narrative. This is what makes the ME series so special, along with it's bigger-than life space opera setting. Finally, I have to say that this game is a bargain. It offers at least 30 hours of gameplay, and if you explore every little corner and do every single side quests, those 30 hours could easily stretch to 50. Get this thing ASAP.

												Mass Effect is one of the greatest RPGs in modern gaming. It definitely makes it in my top 10 games of all time. Even though its combat does seem stale and a bit boring the overall epicness and fun of the story definitely makes up for it. The writing definitely makes you feel like a grand space hero and an important figure. All choices do matter and you regret some of them due to the outcome. The character Customization does fall a little short with very little options to chose from. The game sometimes feels unbalanced and can sometimes be extremely difficult. There are some moments with bad dialogue like during combat with enemy and some NPCs. The overall experience is very grand and very fun but it does have some flaws that are a bit annoying. P.S dont even get me started on the elevator rides on the citadel. I give it a 8.2\10 An Amazing and must own game.

												It did a great job of introducing me to a whole bunch of new philosophical questions at a very basic level when I was 15-16. A great alternative to pamphlets when you need to talk to your 15 year old kid about ending the life support of some crazy lady's husband.One of the available side-quests (colonist background) was one of my favorite moments in any game I've ever played, and was more touching to me than even something like Undertale was.This game played a small role in shaping the person I am, but it did so by presenting me with options and making me choose from them - not by forcing me to play the galaxy's hero or villain. Highly recommended, although parts of the game do show their age these days.

content:
ber 21, 2013
												If you haven't already purchased this game, you should go and purchase it right now.  Why? Well there's plenty of reasons. Mass Effect is the beginning to the phenomenal trilogy that revolutionized what it means to give a player choice.  In this game you are Shepard, a Commander in the Alliance Navy. Essentially you learn that the rogue Spectre, the galaxy's highest ranking police essentially, Saren is attempting to bring back the ancient machine race known as the Reapers. While tracking Saren down, Shepard meets many valuable teammates, and loses them, based on how you play.The dialogue in this game is centered mostly around a wheel with several parts, each having different types of dialogue choices. Want to attempt to save all the survivors of an attack? Sure. Want to punch the ♥♥♥♥♥y news-reporter in her face? Feel free, it's your choice. Choices, which do carry on the sequels, mind you. While the story and dialogue in the first game entice you to finish it, I do have to admit that the combat is not the best. It's pretty bad, but not too bad that it makes it unbearable to play. But don't worry, the problem is solved in the next game so don't lose hope. There are also a few bugs in the game that annoy you sometimes and also a few graphical errors, but nothing that will keep you from enjoying the masterpiece that is Mass Effect.On a scale of 1 to 10, I would gives Mass Effect a 9.2.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2, 2015
One of the best modern story-driven RPG's I've ever played. I have no complaints about ME1. I loved every minute of my 2 playthroughs. On my 5yr old PC there were no graphic glitches, no lag or issues of any kind. Just smooth sailing graphics & a wonderful story. The characters are well-written, even the ones you don't like (looking at you Ashley). As in KOTOR, you can go Light or Dark, good or bad, making Dialog choices to reflect your own personality or how you want Commander Shepard to be perceived. In this game at least, your choices don't really affect the endgame outcome. Your choices DO open up different dialog options and some side quests. It adds fun flavor to the game.I loved finding all the armor & weps scattered around everywhere you go. I liked the hacking puzzle mini-game to open caches. It reminded me of the similar hydraulic puzzle game in Bioshock, which I also loved - both the main game & the mini puzzle game.The DLC is FreeAnother plus for ME1 is the 2 DLC's are free & easily found to download. Some nice people have already linked them in other helpful reviews, or just Google.Common ComplaintsThe MakoSome people complain about the Mako, which if you haven't played the game yet, is a tank-like vehicle you drive when you explore planets. I personally loved driving the crazy thing. Yes, it can be hard to control. Things can get a little wild, but it's really not that hard & once you get the hang of it, driving it literally anywhere is good fun. Mostly though, combat in the thing with its cannon & gun are a literal blast.ExplorationSome people complained about exploring Planets. I personally enjoyed this aspect as well. You only explore at most, 1 planet per system, & exploring each planet only takes a few minutes. Of course, I did really like driving the Mako so any excuse to get in the thing & go nuts was welcome.Game Won't Start, or get a Black or White Screen then game won't startThis did actually happen to me once, but is VERY simple to fix. Find the game's .exe, right click it and select "Open as Administrator". If that doesn't work for you, exit Steam, then Right-click Steam to "Open As", THEN rt click ME1's .exe to "Open As". You should only ever have to do this once, then done. It happened to me at about 5hours in. I was frustrated for about 10 minutes before I found this simple solution. After that I just started the game normally for the rest of my playtime.Other Similar Games I recommend you play:Dragon Age SeriesMass Effect SeriesKOTOR SeriesBioshock Series - Especially 1, 2 & Minerva's Den DLC (Excellent standalone story there)All of those game titles are equal in my esteem. They all provide good value for the price & all have a great story. These games all really draw you in. IMO you just can't go wrong with any of them.Comments About ME2 & 3(*Included here because many people are buying 1&2 here together)While ME1 had only 2 DLC, both of which are now free, ME2 & ME3 both have numerous expensive DLC that never goes on sale. In fact, you can't just "buy" & DL DLC for those 2 games. Nope. Even though you can purchase ME2 on Steam, you have to go to Origin to get the DLC for it.Of course some people needlessly complain about Origin, but truthfully, Origin is awesome. It's a very solid Game Management / Store Interface, just as good as Steam for it's own purposes.Anyway, say you buy the ME1/2 pack here on Steam & you want to then buy DLC for the game, which must be done on Origin (or also on social.bioware.com). ME2/Deluxe does come with a tiny bit of DLC, which you can also activate on Origin along with the base game, should you wish to. Simple steps are needed: Install the game in Steam Right-click ME2 in your Steam library and "View CD Key" (The game must be installed to have this option) Open Origin. If you didn't already, create an account & log in. At the top left, click on Origin, then click "Redeem Product Code" There are 3 codes for ME2. Copy each from the little Steam window, one at a time, then paste to Activate in the Origin app. Find the game in your Origin Library, hover the mouse over it then click the little italicized "i", which opens a more detailed Information page.On the Info page you can see a list of all the DLC, much of which is free. However, the good stuff, namely the Content packs which give you more missions & not just fluff cosmetics, cost money.Actually, they cost "Bioware Points". Yes, it's lame, but there's no way around it. BC although Bioware makes insanely awesome games, the guy in charge of setting up the sale of DLC is obviously a crackhead. There's simply no other explanation for why they think this is a good idea, as opposed to just being able to put all the desired DLC in your cart then buying it all straight up.Nope. You put what you want in the cart, then when you Checkout......it takes you to buy Bioware Points. 1600 Points sells for $20, 1200/$15 & 800/$10. It's very simple math to figure out which DLC you really want then convert the dollar value to how many Bioware Points you need. It's really very annoying, but it's not that complicated.You're going to need ~$40 for all the ME2 DLC. More for ME3. So, even though you probably only paid $20 for all 3 games (on sale of course), you're going to probably be forking out $80+ more dollars for any content & cosmetics you may want for ME2 & ME3.One last note. I hear that DLC you buy for ME2 (in Origin of course) can also be activated in your Steam copy of the game, though I don't see the need to do it, so I've never tried. I honeslty don't know why you wouldn't just play it in Origin. But it's said to be possible should you wish to try it.Hope this info was helpful. Enjoy!

content:
r 12, 2014
												The first thing that comes to mind when I think of Mass Effect is the thoroughness in how well thought out the universe is. The science - what's explained anyway - sounds interesting and plausible (not that I would really know). The concept of labeling any species as "goodguys" or "badguys" is hard to do since there are handfulls of both good and bad for each one (can't quite call any Hannar "bad" but no point nitpicking).The second thing I noticed was the story was really compelling in a way that felt more involving than other games. Think of Mass Effect as a videogame version of a "Choose Your Own Adventure" book. The choices you make can affect huge storylines that span the entire series. Sadly giving examples would spoil them. You can even unlock special actions/comments by raising meters gauging your Paragon and Renegade levels. That said almost every single active side quest was pretty repetitive. Go to planet. Drive on planet. Go in only building on planet. Kill a group of people. Collect loot.The combat is fun. How hard it is almost entirely depends on how well you are equipped. If you and your squad aren't equipped then you'll die sometimes. If they're well equipped most missions will typically be manageable on your first attempts. It might have been easier for me being I was an Engineer on my playthrough though - I destroyed shields and overheated weapons and hacked synthetic enemies to control the crowd a bit. I'm eager to try the game again as another class to see how different it would be.The driving parts with the Mako tank sometimes felt out of place. There were a few times it was major fun to drive. The missions involved obviously intended for the tank - like when driving it in the roofs of the ruins of skyscrapers - were awesome. However almost every planet you go to involves dropping onto the surface with the Mako tank before you drive around to check all the marked spots on a map (technically you could ignore them, but this is the most major way to run acrossed large money and some side-mission peices - which also possibly affect things later in the series). A lot of these worlds were mountainous and would make the Mako tank feel pretty mind numbingly slow on the incline.The inventory system was a mess. You could only hold so many items at a time and these items fill up fast on missions - between times you manage to run into a shop to unload them. This means you end up having to mess with it constantly. It's barely sorted in any way and it randomizes the entire list when you equip anything - making it a pain to find what you look for. It at least only shows items that fit in whatever slot you were trying to equip.The graphics were better than I expected them to be for a 10 year old game. Felt like what I usually have them set at for today's games.This game honestly feels like it should be added to some list of "Games Every Gamer Ought to Play." It feels like I'm playing a legend. Might have been because I've heard it's good for about 10 years.

content:
, 2015
												The first two times I played this game, it was on the lowly XBox 360.  The game was already very dated five years ago, or so it seemed.  My third playthrough, and my first on the PC, and I'm seeing stunning visuals and textures that were simply not present on the console version.  The game looks worlds better than I remember.  Controls are better (except for the vehicle), and it helps to have a deep understanding of game mechanics from playing all three multiple times through.  My first playthrough of this game was frustratingly difficult because I didn't understand what type of character I had picked or how to properly use the powers.  I suggest a revisit to this game for anyone who liked this series.  Tip:  If anyone's having trouble running this game, or using Steam overlay while playing, close Steam, and reopen it as Administrator.  The games will inherit the permissions, and everything will work fine. Tip 2:  For anyone having trouble with resolution settings, dig into the Steam game folder for Mass Effect.  There's a launcher in there that lets you change settings, including increasing resolution (for me, 2560 x 1600, but anything 16:10 will need to be set via this launcher to look correct, because the game will only show 16:9 resolutions while looking at in-game settings.)

content:
0, 2013
												The first part of one of the most immersive and fascinating video game series' of all time. The music alone deserves a playthrough, not to mention the amazing and complex storyline and the many interesting details that can be found throughout the insanely well-crafted universe. I will never forget Chora's Den or Flux (Shepard-dance, anyone?), the heart-wrenching decisions I had to make, the friends I have found (Anderson! Garrus! Wrex!), or the romances I've had (Ashley! Liara!), and despite the evident weaknesses the game has, when it comes to game mechanics for example, it is still one of my all-time favorites, surpassing even the following games, ME2 and ME3, in some areas. Making different decisions does not only change the course of the story, so that you discover new witty and interesting dialogs every time you play through the game (Shepard: "I'm p*ssed off. When I get p*ssed off, I shoot things.", discovered on my 3rd playthrough), they do also have an effect on the two successors. My suggestions is this: Get the game, make your OWN Shepard (not the standard one!) and just f*cking enjoy! Take your time, however: This game is not something for ADS kiddies who usually play CoD or Battlefield. It is like a good book, except for all the additional benefits the medium video game has to offer. A gem of a game for connoisseurs.

content:
23
												"As Commander Shepard, you lead an elite squad on a heroic, action-packed adventure throughout the galaxy."My very first experience with Mass Effect was when I saw the cover of the third game on a shelf when browsing around a shop. I have heard good things on the internet about the franchise and since I couldn't find any copies of the games, I brought this one. When I got home I started up my PS3 and played the game. Obviously I felt a bit lost at first and knew that some things were missing because I hadn't played the previous games, but the experience sure was fun. I then purchased the other two games and a bit of DLC as time went by from the PlayStation Store and played the entire franchise from start to finish. It quickly became one of my favorite gaming franchises. Recetly I bought Mass Effect 1 for PC since it was on sale. I managed to get the two DLCs for free and installed a mod that enchanced the game's overall quality and textures. The perfomance was vastly improved when compared to the console. Instead of the game being locked on 30FPS, I now get around 80 to 130 frames-per-second. So, is this game so good that it was worth a re-purchase? Yes, it is. It's been months since I touched the series and being back sure feels good. Unlike last time, I kind of rushed in order to get to the third game, but this time around I'm going slow. I've already spent forty hours in this and I'm still not finished. I'm taking my time to explore every corner and quest that the game provides. Pros:- You can create your own Shepard and modify his or hers facial features, background and even select a Class. Vanguard is my favorite, but it all depends on taste after all.- The story is great. One of the best out there. No wonder this game was a hit back on 2007. - You control your character at 100%; you make your own choices and the story is tailored by how you play. Most of your choices lead to consequences that will impact future games. - You will either love or hate your companions. They are great characters and will surely provide you aid in combat. Each one of them has a different role, so be sure to think before heading out.- It has one of the best voice-acting out there. Jennifer Hale is the best.- Being a 2007 most computers and laptops nowadays can handle this game with ease and it still looks amazing ten years later. BioWare sure knew what they were doing with their engine back then.- The Mako can be fun and there's some variety put into the side-quests in terms of looks and feel.- This game only came to be thanks to KOTOR, so obviously you will find some nice Star Wars references here and there. Besides those, there are also some other Easter Eggs and even references to older games and subjects. - The RPG and Shooter elements were combined rather nicely. You can select all sorts of gear for your character and companions.- Great soundtrack.- And many others...Cons:- For some people the game might feel outdated... for whatever reason. Most people prefer ME2 and ME3. I personally find all of them good at their own pace.- It's a bit hard to create a good-looking Shepard... but not as hard as some other BioWare games that's for sure.- If careless, you will be blocked from certain choices that will eventually ruin your experience.- The AI isn't amazing. Some enemies will sometimes stare at the walls and your companions will sometimes shoot at you rather than the enemies themselves.- Some people can find the Mako a bore due to its clunky physics and the familiar feeling of most side-quests. There is also a lack of variety in music choice when it comes to these quests.- Some backtracking during missions.- Sometimes the DLC can can be removed by itself. Be sure to save a copy of their installers and a copy of your save files somewhere. However, your computer might consider these save files as malware.- Little variety put into the DLCs. Pinnacle Station feels like it was done by a completely different team.- Even though you have several dialogue choices, some of them can lead to the exact same outcome.- And others.WARNING: The Steam version DOES NOT include any of the DLC. You can easily find it for free just by browsing it on Google with no issues.

												Part of my all time favorite series (seriously why did everyone hate the ending of ME3 so much?) Mass Effect 1 is a great game with an awesome beginning to the grand story of, well, Mass Effect.Just be warned. Quicksave often, since the only autosaves are 4 hours apart, and the game might bore newcomers until they reach Sovereign in one of the later planets. If you aren't hooked after that then Gone Home might be the game for you.
